2018-03-05.abstract: Safe Catch, a canning company that tests for mercury levels, now sells wild pink salmon in addition to sustainably caught tuna.
2018-03-05.snippet: Safe Catch, a canning company that tests for mercury levels, now sells wild pink salmon in addition to sustainably caught tuna.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: Safe Catch, a seafood canning company based in Sausalito, Calif., tests for mercury levels and rejects about 25 percent of the fish for not meeting its standards. It started with sustainably caught tuna and has now introduced canned wild pink salmon, a succulent, mild-tasting fish that can be used in salads, casseroles and sandwiches, among other recipes. There’s also a low-sodium version: Safe Catch Wild Pink Salmon, five-ounce cans, six for $26.99, safecatch.com.
2018-03-05.headline_main: Canned Salmon With Lower Mercury Levels

2018-03-05.abstract: Hosting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the president said he still had “a good chance” of forging peace, but a deal seems further away than ever.
2018-03-05.snippet: Hosting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the president said he still had “a good chance” of forging peace, but a deal seems further away than ever.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the midst of his campaign, President Trump vowed to bring peace to the Middle East by playing it down the middle between Israel and the Palestinians. “Let me be sort of a neutral guy,” he said. Two years later, any hopes of being the neutral guy are long gone.
2018-03-05.headline_main: Trump’s Hopes of Being the ‘Neutral Guy’ in the Mideast Seem Long Gone

2018-03-05.abstract: A South American hummingbird’s noise is well above the normal hearing range of most birds, perhaps to stand out amid the din of other species in its habitat.
2018-03-05.snippet: A South American hummingbird’s noise is well above the normal hearing range of most birds, perhaps to stand out amid the din of other species in its habitat.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: Claudio Mello was conducting research in Brazil’s Atlantic Forest about 20 years ago when he heard a curious sound. It was high-pitched and reedy, like a pin scratching metal.
2018-03-05.headline_main: This Hummingbird Chirps Like an Insect. Can It Hear Its Own Sound?

2018-03-05.abstract: In a wide-ranging discussion, our critics examine how the Academy Awards were actually in tune with these polarizing times.
2018-03-05.snippet: In a wide-ranging discussion, our critics examine how the Academy Awards were actually in tune with these polarizing times.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: An awards season dominated by #MeToo ended with the Oscars on Sunday. The New York Times’s co-chief film critics, Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, and the critic at large Wesley Morris discussed the telecast and what it said about Hollywood and our moment.
2018-03-05.headline_main: #MeToo, Harvey Weinstein and Awkward TV: Our Critics Talk Oscars

2018-03-05.abstract: Jennifer Clair focuses on knife skills, meat cookery, pan sauces, roasting vegetables, blanching vegetables and preparing leafy greens in her new book.
2018-03-05.snippet: Jennifer Clair focuses on knife skills, meat cookery, pan sauces, roasting vegetables, blanching vegetables and preparing leafy greens in her new book.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Clair, who has taught small hands-on cooking classes in Manhattan since 2002, has assembled some essential lessons in a book. “Six Basic Cooking Techniques” uses straightforward text and photos to cover knife skills, meat cookery, pan sauces, roasting vegetables, blanching vegetables and preparing leafy greens. Each section gives a handful of recipes, mostly simple and very sound, and advice on equipment. But I was surprised that she does not mention cast iron as an option for skillets: “Six Basic Cooking Techniques: Culinary Essentials for the Home Cook” (HCNY Press, $19.95), homecookingny.com.
2018-03-05.headline_main: An Instruction Book on Six Basics of Cooking

2018-03-05.abstract: Uzodinma Iweala’s second novel, “Speak No Evil,” is about what happens when the wealthy and conservative parents of a track star headed to Harvard find out he’s gay.
2018-03-05.snippet: Uzodinma Iweala’s second novel, “Speak No Evil,” is about what happens when the wealthy and conservative parents of a track star headed to Harvard find out he’s gay.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: The jury is out on whether dating apps like Happn and Grindr are bad for society or simply bad for the future of vowels. They’re plainly no help to Niru, the teenage boy at the center of “Speak No Evil,” Uzodinma Iweala’s second novel.
2018-03-05.headline_main: A Young Man of Strict Nigerian-American Parents Comes of Age While Coming Out

2018-03-05.abstract: The practice of attaching a CD to concert tickets is a favorite of older rock bands. It helped Bon Jovi dethrone the “Black Panther” soundtrack after two weeks at the top.
2018-03-05.snippet: The practice of attaching a CD to concert tickets is a favorite of older rock bands. It helped Bon Jovi dethrone the “Black Panther” soundtrack after two weeks at the top.

2018-03-05.abstract: In his second attempt to replace Carmen Fariña, the mayor selected Richard A. Carranza, the Houston schools superintendent, who accepted at City Hall.

2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: There were two finalists in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s search for a new schools chancellor, and on Monday, just days after being spurned by his first choice, the mayor said the job would go to the runner-up, Richard A. Carranza, the superintendent of the Houston schools.

2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The message coming out of an investment conference here in February was simple and optimistic: “Puerto Rico is open for business.” Attendees noted San Juan’s crowded restaurants and traffic-choked streets. The capital city seemed to be bustling.
2018-03-05.headline_main: Puerto Rico’s Positive Business Slogans Can’t Keep the Lights On

2018-03-05.abstract: Donald Trump and his supporters on the right have been more effective than liberals in using internet memes to promote ideas and attack enemies.
2018-03-05.snippet: Donald Trump and his supporters on the right have been more effective than liberals in using internet memes to promote ideas and attack enemies.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: Say the word “meme” and most people think of funny videos that go viral or assaults by internet trolls on platforms like 4chan, a website frequented by alt-right groups. President Trump, who regularly retweets memes, many of them directed at Democrats, is perhaps the most famous devotee of the form.
2018-03-05.headline_main: The Left Shouldn’t Be Too Proud to Meme

2018-03-05.abstract: Does Russia really have ability to destroy American defenses?
2018-03-05.snippet: Does Russia really have ability to destroy American defenses?

2018-03-05.abstract: Cerasum is made from Michigan cherries and blossoms from Virginia. It makes a nice mixer.
2018-03-05.snippet: Cerasum is made from Michigan cherries and blossoms from Virginia. It makes a nice mixer.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: Before the fruity cherry notes hit the palate, you are confronted with intriguing, dusky bitterness, the kind of taste that drives the best amaros. Cerasum, a new cherry liqueur, made in the United States by Don Ciccio & Figli from Michigan cherries and blossoms from Virginia, plus assorted herbs like juniper, is based on an old Italian recipe. It’s not sweet. I prefer it as a mixer rather than as a straight drink. A splash does admirably in sparkling wine, and can contribute a subtle fruity note to a Manhattan: Cerasum Aperitivo, $46 for 750 milliliters at Mouth Indie Spirits and Wine Gallery, 192 Water Street (Jay Street), Brooklyn, 347-227-7007, mouth.com; $44.99 at Cordial Craft Wine, Beer & Spirits in Washington, 202-548-2450, cordialwine.com.
2018-03-05.headline_main: A New Cherry Liqueur, Made in America

2018-03-05.abstract: The California-based Shed restaurant offers up meaty slices of mushrooms that go nicely on an antipasto platter, sandwiches or seared fish.
2018-03-05.snippet: The California-based Shed restaurant offers up meaty slices of mushrooms that go nicely on an antipasto platter, sandwiches or seared fish.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: Generously meaty slices of shiitake mushrooms pickled with tamari, vinegar and seaweed have been given a salty tang by Shed, a restaurant and food purveyor in Healdsburg, Calif. A bowl of them with toothpicks for stabbing can go on that antipasto platter, they add zest to grilled-cheese sandwiches or panini, and you could dice them to scatter on seared fish, just as you would capers: Pickled shiitake mushrooms, $18 for 13.5 ounces, healdsburgshed.com.
2018-03-05.headline_main: Pickled Shiitake Mushrooms With a Salty Tang

2018-03-05.abstract: The Meat Hook in Brooklyn offers classes in sausage-making and pig butchering.
2018-03-05.snippet: The Meat Hook in Brooklyn offers classes in sausage-making and pig butchering.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: The Meat Hook butcher shop, which moved from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to the border of Greenpoint a couple of years ago, is also in charge of the restaurant inside the sprawling Threes Brewing in Gowanus. And it’s there that the partners, Brent Young and Benjamin Turley, run classes given by the butcher Leah Wolfe. Coming up are sessions in sausage-making and pig butchering. Each class, from 5 to 7 p.m., includes some snacks and a couple of beers: Sausage-making, $95, March 18, April 15; Pig Butchering, $85, April 1, Meat Hook at Threes Brewing, 333 Douglass Street (Fourth Avenue), Gowanus, Brooklyn, 718-522-2110, the-meathook.com.
2018-03-05.headline_main: Learning How the Sausage Is Made

2018-03-05.abstract: The appropriation of a feminist theme for selling whiskey to women is nothing if not ironic.
2018-03-05.snippet: The appropriation of a feminist theme for selling whiskey to women is nothing if not ironic.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: Jane Walker will take over her brother Johnny’s whiskey label this month — in honor of Women’s History Month, we’re told — a temporary rebranding that’s fueling comic riffs by Stephen Colbert and other cynical types. It might seem innocuous enough — an unsubtle attempt to lure skittish female drinkers to whiskey — but there’s a back story to this relationship that’s worth noting.
2018-03-05.headline_main: Women, Booze and the Vote

2018-03-05.snippet: Paul D. Ryan has modeled himself as the face of a new brand of conservatism. But critics say he has abandoned his principles and is too deferential to President Trump.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan, a fierce believer in America as a land of immigrants, recently attended a dinner party with a so-called Dreamer. When she pleaded with him to help young undocumented immigrants like herself gain legal status, he hesitated — the House, he said, would pass only legislation that President Trump would sign.

2018-03-05.abstract: Marisa Wu’s Salty Road gives a chewy treat a kick-start.
2018-03-05.snippet: Marisa Wu’s Salty Road gives a chewy treat a kick-start.
2018-03-05.lead_paragraph: For me, saltwater taffy is like a martini: Consuming either one is a slow process. And while martinis evoke Chumley’s back in the day, saltwater taffy always brings to mind family trips to Atlantic City when I was much younger. These days, for saltwater taffy, count on Marisa Wu’s Salty Road. Give her credit for helping to revive this treat, starting seven years ago in Brooklyn. She offers a raft of flavors, the latest of which are sunny banana, made with caramelized fresh banana purée, and tart passion fruit: The Salty Road Salt Water Taffy, $10 for 3.5 ounces or three 3.5-ounce bags for $21, thesaltyroad.com.
2018-03-05.headline_main: A Little Taffy Stretches the Memory

2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: Norristown, Pa. — Lawyers for Bill Cosby argued in court on Monday that documents — including his accuser’s phone records and Mr. Cosby’s travel records — contradict her testimony about when she says the entertainer sexual assaulted her.
2018-03-06.headline_main: Bill Cosby’s Retrial Proceeds as Judge Rejects Motions to Dismiss

2018-03-06.abstract: The performance by Daniela Vega in the film has given a face and a voice to the plight of Chile’s transgender community.
2018-03-06.snippet: The performance by Daniela Vega in the film has given a face and a voice to the plight of Chile’s transgender community.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — A bill that would give transgender Chileans the right to change their name and gender marker in official documents had been advancing at a glacial pace since a handful of lawmakers introduced it in May 2013.
2018-03-06.headline_main: Oscar for ‘A Fantastic Woman’ Bolsters Chile Gender Identity Bill

2018-03-06.abstract: Kansas City reached two World Series with Eric Hosmer and Lorenzo Cain, but couldn’t afford to keep them. They will take what they learned to San Diego and Milwaukee.
2018-03-06.snippet: Kansas City reached two World Series with Eric Hosmer and Lorenzo Cain, but couldn’t afford to keep them. They will take what they learned to San Diego and Milwaukee.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Early in Eric Hosmer’s career, when it was clear he would be a star first baseman, a fan at a Rotary Club asked a pointed question to Dayton Moore, the general manager of the Kansas City Royals. For decades, the fans had yearned for a player like Hosmer with the talent and charisma to stir a dormant franchise. But this fan was worried. He wanted to know if the Royals could possibly sign Hosmer to a long-term contract.
2018-03-06.headline_main: After Reviving the Royals, Hosmer and Cain Try to Spark Other Teams

2018-03-06.abstract: A special committee of the company’s board said a roughly $8.3 billion offer, or $50 a share, was too low.
2018-03-06.snippet: A special committee of the company’s board said a roughly $8.3 billion offer, or $50 a share, was too low.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: Nordstrom’s long, winding attempt to move into private ownership took another turn Monday. A special committee of the retailer’s board rejected a roughly $8.4 billion offer from the Nordstrom family to buy the company, saying the price was too low.
2018-03-06.headline_main: Nordstrom Family’s Bid to Buy the Retailer Is Rejected

2018-03-06.abstract: A flood of migrants and years of stagnation sent traditional parties reeling.
2018-03-06.snippet: A flood of migrants and years of stagnation sent traditional parties reeling.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: The Italian elections on Sunday were the latest powerful wave in a tidal turn of anti-immigrant, anti-European Union and antidemocratic fervor that has ravaged European politics. The vote was a stinging rejection of traditional parties, and of national leadership that has been frustrated by a flood of migrants from Africa and the Middle East and stymied by years of stagnation.
2018-03-06.headline_main: Demagogues Win as Europe’s Populist Tide Sweeps Italy

2018-03-06.abstract: There won’t be a snap back to the democracy we knew before.
2018-03-06.snippet: There won’t be a snap back to the democracy we knew before.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: What happens to American politics after Donald Trump? Do we snap back to normal or do things spin ever more widely out of control?
2018-03-06.headline_main: The Chaos After Trump

2018-03-06.abstract: Richard A. Carranza grew up in Arizona and worked his way through college as a musician. He described himself as “a mariachi masquerading as a superintendent.”
2018-03-06.snippet: Richard A. Carranza grew up in Arizona and worked his way through college as a musician. He described himself as “a mariachi masquerading as a superintendent.”
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: It was not a conventional job interview. At one of his first meetings with Mayor Bill de Blasio and his wife, Chirlane McCray, to discuss the job of New York City schools chancellor, Richard A. Carranza serenaded them with a mariachi song: “Maria Elena.”
2018-03-06.headline_main: Next to Lead New York’s Schools: An Educator With a Song on His Lips

2018-03-06.abstract: Investment firms like Larry Fink’s BlackRock have preached social responsibility. With guns, they can use their influence to achieve it.
2018-03-06.snippet: Investment firms like Larry Fink’s BlackRock have preached social responsibility. With guns, they can use their influence to achieve it.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: Over the past several weeks, there has been a lot of talk about investors ridding themselves of their shares in gun manufacturers and retailers after the school shooting in Parkland, Fla. A number of public pension funds, like those in the state of Connecticut, have discussed the prospect of selling their shares.
2018-03-06.headline_main: Big Investors Have Clout. They Can Use It With Gun Makers.

2018-03-06.abstract: All over the United States, women are leading citizen rebellions.
2018-03-06.snippet: All over the United States, women are leading citizen rebellions.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, The Washington Post ran a long piece about West Virginia called, “How the birthplace of the American labor movement just turned on its unions.” It described how, following the Republican takeover of the Legislature in 2014, the state passed a so-called right-to-work law prohibiting mandatory union dues. Such laws have badly undermined unions in other states, and for people who care about organized labor, it was a bitter irony to see one enacted in a place once famed for its militant labor movement. The state also repealed a law mandating that workers on public construction projects are paid prevailing industry rates. Labor in West Virginia seemed beaten down.
2018-03-06.headline_main: The Teachers Revolt in West Virginia

2018-03-06.abstract: Written by the screenwriter, director and novelist John Sayles, this week’s episode swapped action for oratory punch.
2018-03-06.snippet: Written by the screenwriter, director and novelist John Sayles, this week’s episode swapped action for oratory punch.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: Like the killer himself, the action and suspense that fueled last week’s intense and engaging episode of “The Alienist” slinked back into the shadows this time around. But what this week’s episode lacks in adrenaline it makes up for in oratory. Written by the screenwriter, director and novelist John Sayles, the episode features meaty near-monologues from a variety of characters, all of whom offer insight into the evil that people do.
2018-03-06.headline_main: ‘The Alienist’ Season 1, Episode 7: A Devil’s Bargain

2018-03-06.abstract: Bruce Greig makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
2018-03-06.snippet: Bruce Greig makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — When someone makes his or her New York Times Crossword debut, I try to give the puzzle maker room to learn as I consider that first creation. Not everyone will have an immediate grasp of what makes interesting fill, or whether an entry might be jarring in a grid. Hopefully, with time, these constructors will adapt their word lists and learn to put aside themes until they can give them more thought.
2018-03-06.headline_main: Part of Who I Am

2018-03-06.headline_main: He Turned on Al Qaeda and Aided the U.S. Now He’s on Food Stamps and Needs a Job.

2018-03-06.abstract: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2018-03-06.snippet: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: HOPE NATION. Edited by Rose Brock. Read by a full cast of contributors, including Angie Thomas, David Levithan and Jason Reynolds. (Listening Library.) A collection of essays and intimate recollections by some of today’s most celebrated young adult authors dedicated to emboldening teenage audiences through the power of optimism. HEART TALK. By Cleo Wade. Read by the author. (Simon & Schuster Audio.) Her inspiring micro-life-lessons have become a hit on Instagram, but the artist, poet and social media phenomenon’s own idiosyncratic voice makes her spiritual and practical wisdom even more forceful. HOW TO AMERICAN: An Immigrant’s Guide to Disappointing Your Parents. By Jimmy O. Yang. Read by the author. (Hachette Audio.) The “Silicon Valley” star blends humor and pathos in his coming-of-age memoir, revealing the intricacies of life as a Chinese immigrant growing up in California, from cultural assimilation to interracial dating. THE ESCAPE ARTIST. By Brad Meltzer. Read by Scott Brick and January LaVoy. (Hachette Audio.) The veteran audiobook narrators bring to life the best-selling author’s latest military thriller, about a soldier who was once presumed dead but is now discovered to be on the run. RAW. By Lamont “U-God” Hawkins. Read by the author. (Macmillan Audio.) A gritty and uplifting account of the author’s path from a single-parent childhood on the rough streets of Brooklyn to becoming a hip-hop legend as a member of the Wu-Tang Clan.
2018-03-06.headline_main: New & Noteworthy

2018-03-06.abstract: Stomp Sessions, a new app created by former professional extreme sports athletes, helps link up skaters and riders with athletes for lessons.
2018-03-06.snippet: Stomp Sessions, a new app created by former professional extreme sports athletes, helps link up skaters and riders with athletes for lessons.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: For the past month, Julia Mancuso, the former Olympic skier and multiple medal winner, was perched high in the Pyeongchang mountains for NBC, offering her analysis for the millions tuned into the network’s coverage. But in March, Ms. Mancuso will be back on the mountain, offering tips and insight in private ski and snowboard sessions. The secret to unlocking these seemingly exclusive and in-demand insights from the top pros of the sport? It’s through a newly launched app called Stomp Sessions.
2018-03-06.headline_main: An App That Helps You Ride Like a Pro — by Riding With a Pro

2018-03-06.abstract: Did our 52 Places Traveler love Disney Springs, Fla.? No. But she did love that other people love it.
2018-03-06.snippet: Did our 52 Places Traveler love Disney Springs, Fla.? No. But she did love that other people love it.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: “I’d like to make you what’s called a gris-gris. It’s a good-luck charm for all your travels,” said Meraux Dantes, a magician who had just walked over to me in Disney Springs, Fla. In short order, he’d have me bend a fork with my mind. This, it became clear, was his job. (Gris-gris originated in West Africa and are often worn as amulets or embedded in the entryway of a house to protect against theft.)
2018-03-06.headline_main: Place 4 of 52: Magical and Not-So-Magical Moments in Disney’s Adults-Mostly, Artificial Paradise

2018-03-06.abstract: A mother and daughter have plenty of time to enjoy Stockholm, Copenhagen and St. Petersburg on their cruise as well as sashimi and scavenger hunts onboard.
2018-03-06.snippet: A mother and daughter have plenty of time to enjoy Stockholm, Copenhagen and St. Petersburg on their cruise as well as sashimi and scavenger hunts onboard.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: A cruise wasn’t even a contender when my 8-year-old daughter, Meenakshi, and I were planning our summer vacation. The two cruises I had taken more than 15 years ago had left me certain that I would never go on another. I craved the freedom to explore a destination untethered by time constraints, but how do you do that on a cruise when you have a deadline to be onboard by late afternoon before the ship departs for the next port?
2018-03-06.headline_main: A Tale of Three Cities, With a Ship as Home Base

2018-03-06.abstract: More than a year after his death, the poet, novelist and singer-songwriter is experiencing a cultural resurgence in the city of his birth.
2018-03-06.snippet: More than a year after his death, the poet, novelist and singer-songwriter is experiencing a cultural resurgence in the city of his birth.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — In an octagonal chamber at the Musée d’Art Contemporain de Montréal, a spectator in a trance-like state hums Leonard Cohen’s “Hallelujah” as numbers on a digital display leap up to 631. That’s how many people on Earth are streaming Cohen’s version of the secular anthem right now, each represented by a recorded voice humming the song.
2018-03-06.headline_main: Is Leonard Cohen the New Secular Saint of Montreal?

2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England —  Some of the women have blue hair, others, purple, some long and plaited, others short and shaved on the sides. Tattoos depicting skates, roses and eagle feathers peek out from behind their elbowpads and kneepads. They wear a streak of red makeup across their face with three dots below it, symbolizing three matriarchal generations: the grandmother, the mother and the self.
2018-03-06.headline_main: ‘Decolonizing’ Roller Derby? Team Indigenous Takes Up the Challenge

2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: Tesla has practically had the market for pavement-scorching long-range electric vehicles all to itself. But consumers will soon have a lot more choices to compare with the Model S sedan and its sport-utility sibling, the Model X. And those offerings will be coming from established luxury brands that will be able to take advantage of tax breaks, just as they start to run out for the segment’s dominant brand.

He is also the state’s governor, who switched from Republican to Democrat when he ran for office, then back to Republican last year. 2018-03-06.abstract: In calling for more troops, the general wasn’t guilty of hubris. He was guilty of naïveté.
2018-03-06.snippet: In calling for more troops, the general wasn’t guilty of hubris. He was guilty of naïveté.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: Poor William Westmoreland. No one understood him. General Westmoreland’s forces and their South Vietnamese allies had fended off the attacks of National Liberation Front and North Vietnamese forces at the Vietnamese new year, Tet. He claimed victory. Alluding to Nazi Germany’s defeat in World War II, Westmoreland had compared the enemy at Tet to the Germans at the Battle of the Bulge. He considered the Liberation Front and the North Vietnamese on the ropes, and headed for defeat.
2018-03-06.headline_main: Who Threw Westmoreland Under the Bus?

2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: EMP SUMMER HOUSE The popular summer outpost in East Hampton, N.Y., that Will Guidara and the chef Daniel Humm of Eleven Madison Park ran last year returns, starting May 25 and running Wednesdays to Sundays through mid-September. It will again feature casual indoor and outdoor dining on the lawn and covered patio, with a somewhat more formal menu in the dining room inside. Lobster tempura, tomato salad and rib-eye for two are likely to be served. Large-format dinners for groups of six to eight will again be available. Unlike last season’s pop-up, which was a way to keep staff employed while Eleven Madison Park underwent renovations, this one will hire mainly from the community. The success of the experiment led Mr. Humm and Mr. Guidara’s Make It Nice group to plan a similar winter branch, to open in December, in Aspen, Colo. Both will be run in partnership with American Express, the only credit card accepted at the pop-ups. Starting May 1, reservations for the indoor dining room can be made online through June 30; as of June 1, they can be made through July 31, and starting July 1, they will be taken through September: 341 Pantigo Road, East Hampton, N.Y., empsummerhouse.com.
2018-03-06.headline_main: EMP Summer House Returns to the Hamptons

2018-03-06.snippet: For the 20th anniversary of “The Big Lebowski,” we’ve compiled a list of great and streamable films that follow in the footsteps of el Duderino.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: Two decades have passed since Joel and Ethan Coen introduced the world to the White Russian-slugging Jeffrey Lebowski (Jeff Bridges) — better known as the Dude — and the hair-trigger Vietnam vet Walter Sobchak (John Goodman). And in that time, “The Big Lebowski” has become a dorm-room staple, inspired an annual festival and spawned a pseudo-religion called Dudeism. A clever riff on the gumshoe fiction of Raymond Chandler, “Lebowski” made its widespread theatrical debut 20 years ago, and although the academy has certainly favored the Coens’ more serious films, nothing has compared in terms of cultural impact.
2018-03-06.headline_main: The Little Lebowskis: 10 Righteous Heirs to a Coen Brothers’ Classic

2018-03-06.abstract: The new CW series, beginning Wednesday, tracks a young woman who is newly free of both cancer and dramatic conflict.
2018-03-06.snippet: The new CW series, beginning Wednesday, tracks a young woman who is newly free of both cancer and dramatic conflict.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: CW has 15 scripted shows for the 2017-18 season. Eight are based on comic books; two more are based on existing properties; one is the long-running stalwart “Supernatural” and another is a likely-to-be-canceled military drama. Then there are the two quirky, critical beloved genre-benders: “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend,” a dark-comedy musical, and “Jane the Virgin,” a sudsy but deeply sincere telenovela. Which brings us to “Life Sentence,” starting Wednesday, neither superhero nor supernatural nor super bold. Instead, it feels like the straightforward family drama of CW’s — and WB’s — past: light, young, heartfelt. It’s also unmoored, though, without a clear anchor or companion, putting the show in the unenviable position of having to stand on its own right from the start. It’s enough to crush a mightier, meatier show. But then, “Life Sentence” is all about surprise survival.
2018-03-06.headline_main: Review: On ‘Life Sentence,’ Life Is a Little Too Beautiful

2018-03-06.abstract: ‘The Big Picture’ builds a compelling narrative by telling the stories of the executives whose careers were destroyed or made by the changes to the film industry.
2018-03-06.snippet: ‘The Big Picture’ builds a compelling narrative by telling the stories of the executives whose careers were destroyed or made by the changes to the film industry.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: News flash: Movie studios have come to rely overwhelmingly on “sequels, reboots, spinoffs, adaptations, and animated movies” and “now exist primarily for the purpose of building and supporting branded franchises.” By contrast, the number of original scripted television series commissioned continues to break records, reaching almost 500 in 2017. The challenge for The Wall Street Journal’s entertainment reporter Ben Fritz’s new book, “The Big Picture: The Fight for the Future of Movies,” is to build a compelling business narrative from phenomena that are obvious to anyone who has walked by a multiplex and has a subscription to Netflix or Amazon Prime. Despite some distracting lapses, to a surprising degree he succeeds.

Or maybe two guests did.

2018-03-06.abstract: Francesca DiMattio creates dazzling porcelain works and paintings at her studio in Hillsdale, New York.
2018-03-06.snippet: Francesca DiMattio creates dazzling porcelain works and paintings at her studio in Hillsdale, New York.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: The artist Francesca DiMattio is zigzagging across her vast, warehouselike studio in the rural town of Hillsdale, N.Y., simultaneously firing porcelain, hand-painting ceramic flowers and touching up pottery glazes for three different sculptures. Wearing a paint-splattered brown mechanic’s suit, crowned with her signature Frida Kahlo-esque braids and vibrant coral lips, she is a portrait of elegant incongruity. “I’m really interested in contrast,” she says, “and it’s something I always want in my life.”
2018-03-06.headline_main: The Artist Testing the Limits of Ceramics

2018-03-06.abstract: Small, urban green spaces provide an unexpected benefit in the fight against climate change, a new study shows.
2018-03-06.snippet: Small, urban green spaces provide an unexpected benefit in the fight against climate change, a new study shows.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: As the verdant hills of Wakanda are secretly enriched with the fictional metal vibranium in “Black Panther,” your average backyard also has hidden superpowers: Its soil can absorb and store a significant amount of carbon from the air, unexpectedly making such green spaces an important asset in the battle against climate change.

2018-03-06.abstract: The chain of record stores run by Russ Solomon, who died on Sunday at 92, defined the retail music business in the predigital era, with stars and fans embracing its slogan: “No Music, No Life.”
2018-03-06.snippet: The chain of record stores run by Russ Solomon, who died on Sunday at 92, defined the retail music business in the predigital era, with stars and fans embracing its slogan: “No Music, No Life.”
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: Russ Solomon, who died on Sunday at 92, created what for many music fans was the ultimate music emporium: Tower Records, whose yellow-and-red color scheme, “No Music, No Life” slogan, and wide aisles stocked with LPs and CDs defined the retail music business in the pre-digital era. At its peak, the chain had nearly 200 stores in 15 countries and more than $1 billion in annual sales, before debt and shifting consumer habits forced it to close in 2006.
2018-03-06.headline_main: The Power of Tower Records

2018-03-06.abstract: Our insistence on ascribing characteristics to entire generations is silly and can actually be harmful.
2018-03-06.snippet: Our insistence on ascribing characteristics to entire generations is silly and can actually be harmful.
2018-03-06.lead_paragraph: The Pew Research Center announced last week that it will define people born between 1981 and 1996 as members of the millennial generation, embracing a slightly narrower range of years than the ones used by the United States Census Bureau. It would have been better, though, if it had announced the end of what I call the “generation game” — the insistence on dividing society into groups based on birth year and imputing different characteristics to each group.
2018-03-06.headline_main: ‘Millennial’ Means Nothing

2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: In the catalog of horrors afflicting the world’s most hellish places, South Sudan can check about every bloodied box. More than four years of civil warfare has left tens of thousands dead, two million displaced, half the population at threat of starvation without aid and a trail of atrocities — genocide, child warriors, rape, castration, burned villages. 2018-03-07.abstract: The return of the J.A.S.A. crossword constructing class, ably assisted by Natan Last and Andy Kravis.
2018-03-07.snippet: The return of the J.A.S.A. crossword constructing class, ably assisted by Natan Last and Andy Kravis.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Today’s crossword is brought to us by the J.A.S.A. crossword class, run by the Jewish Association Serving the Aging in New York City. Open to anyone over the age of 55 in the New York City area, the class outlines the basic principles of crossword puzzle construction, beginning with basic crossword history and then focusing on how to come up with a theme, designing a usable grid and creating the fill. At the end of the semester, the group constructs one final puzzle to submit to The New York Times and, while there is no guarantee that the submission will be published, this is the J.A.S.A. class’s 14th puzzle for The Times. That’s a pretty good track record. For more information about this class and the “Sundays at J.A.S.A.” series, see the bottom of today’s column.

2018-03-07.snippet: Travelers often think they have to travel far abroad to take in majestic wildlife, but there’s an abundance of natural beauty right here in the U.S. worth checking out.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: Think you need to travel to the African savanna or South American rain forest to see fantastic wildlife? Think again. According to Martha Kauffman, a managing director and scientist at the World Wildlife Fund, the United States has an abundance of opportunities for memorable wildlife encounters. “The U.S. is home to thousands of species of wildlife, and it’s possible to see lots of these animals up close in their natural habitats,” she said.

While it’s true that Nancy Silverton’s pioneering La Brea Bakery has produced artisan loaves since 1989, the area, rightly or wrongly, has a deeply entrenched reputation as a place where gluten fears to tread.

2018-03-07.abstract: With “Angels in America” about to reopen on Broadway, the 61-year-old playwright is feeling serene — at least by his own intense standards. Don’t get him started on the president, though.
2018-03-07.snippet: With “Angels in America” about to reopen on Broadway, the 61-year-old playwright is feeling serene — at least by his own intense standards. Don’t get him started on the president, though.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: In characteristic fashion, Tony Kushner is doing too many things at once these days, and he’s late with a lot of them. In one more or less typical stretch last month, he was sorting through 60 boxes of his papers, inhaling dust mites in the process; working on a screenplay for Brad Pitt and finishing another, a new version of “West Side Story,” for Steven Spielberg; debating whether to rewrite his first play, “A Bright Room Called Day”; pondering one that might or might not turn out to be about President Trump; finishing the second act of an opera he is writing with Jeanine Tesori about the death of Eugene O’Neill; and vigilantly attending rehearsals of the National Theater’s revival of “Angels in America,” starring Andrew Garfield and Nathan Lane, which has moved from London to Broadway, where it opens March 25 at the Neil Simon Theater.
2018-03-07.headline_main: Tony Kushner, at Peace? Not Exactly. But Close.

2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: Kevin Zeich had three and a half years to go on his prison sentence, but his doctors told him he had less than half that long to live. Nearly blind, battling cancer and virtually unable to eat, he requested “compassionate release,” a special provision for inmates who are very sick or old.
2018-03-07.headline_main: Frail, Old and Dying, but Their Only Way Out of Prison Is a Coffin

2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: A year ago, partly in response to the election, I began compiling pictures of black houses on Pinterest and persuaded my husband that we should paint our house some shade of black. I stayed in a black cabin in the Hudson Valley on a retreat with a girlfriend. I collected paint chips, like Benjamin Moore’s Soot. I wanted my house to be, as Morrissey crooned, “The color I feel inside.”

2018-03-07.abstract: At opposite ends of England’s south coast, galleries are exploring the writing of T.S. Eliot and Virginia Woolf with exhibitions of visual art.
2018-03-07.snippet: At opposite ends of England’s south coast, galleries are exploring the writing of T.S. Eliot and Virginia Woolf with exhibitions of visual art.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: MARGATE, England — At the eastern and western extremes of England’s coast this spring, art galleries are celebrating the life and work of two giants of British modernism. But the artists at the center of these exhibitions aren’t painters or sculptors — they are the writers T.S. Eliot and Virginia Woolf. Diverse in content, featuring visual art from the 1920s up to the present day, the shows use their literary starting points to explore the relationship between the self and nature, as well as the dramatic social upheavals of the authors’ times.
2018-03-07.headline_main: 2 Literary Greats, in Art Galleries by the Sea

2018-03-07.abstract: An exhibition in Vienna explores the role that Jewish philosophers, politicians and artists played in building communism and international socialism.
2018-03-07.snippet: An exhibition in Vienna explores the role that Jewish philosophers, politicians and artists played in building communism and international socialism.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The centenary of the Russian Revolution has inspired dozens of exhibitions of the art and history of the abbreviated Soviet century, from “Revolution: Russian Art 1917—1932,” at London’s Royal Academy, to the Art Institute of Chicago’s “Revoliutsiia! Demonstratsiia!”, not to mention significant shows in Moscow and St. Petersburg. Curators and historians have been grappling once again with the meaning of the 10 days that shook the world: Was it a brilliant dream? A doomed illusion?
2018-03-07.headline_main: The Jews Who Dreamed of Utopia

2018-03-07.headline_main: If Your Uber Ride Cost an Extra $50, Would You Still Take It?

2018-03-07.abstract: Happiness in love, and happiness watching TV, both come with a price.
2018-03-07.snippet: Happiness in love, and happiness watching TV, both come with a price.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: The saga of Arie Luyendyk Jr. on ABC’s 22nd season of “The Bachelor” ended in a two-part finale, stretched agonizingly over two nights. On the first night, viewers watched Mr. Luyendyk choose Becca Kufrin as his wife and then, after several weeks of coupledom, break up with her in horror-film-like real-time footage to pursue the show’s runner-up, Lauren Burnham. On the second night, he proposed to Ms. Burnham before a live studio audience. She accepted, they were hurried offstage, and the wronged woman, Ms. Kufrin, was anointed as the next star of the dual franchise. She accepted the awkward live praise of a cavalcade of men who will woo her for our benefit this spring on “The Bachelorette” — should we choose to watch.
2018-03-07.headline_main: The Endless and Painful ‘Most Dramatic Finale Ever’ of ‘The Bachelor’

2018-03-07.abstract: Balkrishna Doshi, who won this year's Pritzker Prize, asks: “What is the role of an architect today, or are we going to be useful to the society at large?”

2018-03-07.headline_main: Top Architecture Prize Goes to Low-Cost Housing Pioneer From India

2018-03-07.abstract: A startling variety of art ranging cross three millenniums will be on exhibit at museums around the country this spring.
2018-03-07.snippet: A startling variety of art ranging cross three millenniums will be on exhibit at museums around the country this spring.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: BOSTON “Fra Angelico: Heaven on Earth.” This exhibition is something of a reunion: In the early 1400s, the Renaissance artist Fra Angelico did four reliquaries depicting events in the life of the Virgin Mary. In 1899, the newly widowed American collector Isabella Stewart Gardner bought one of them, “Assumption and Dormition of the Virgin,” and brought it back to Boston. Now its three companions, from the Museo de San Marco in Florence, are coming to visit. Through May 20. Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, 25 Evans Way; 617-566-1401,gardnermuseum.org
2018-03-07.headline_main: From 12th Century B.C. to 2017, Art in Startling Variety

2018-03-07.abstract: The British pop duo, whose ballet “The Most Incredible Thing” has its American premiere this week, have always been interested in the classical arts.
2018-03-07.snippet: The British pop duo, whose ballet “The Most Incredible Thing” has its American premiere this week, have always been interested in the classical arts.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When he was 8, two decades before he became the singing half of the British pop duo Pet Shop Boys, Neil Tennant wanted to be a ballet dancer. The Royal Ballet had visited Newcastle, England, where the Tennant family lived, so he saw “Giselle” and (he thinks) “Coppélia.” He was so impressed, he checked out “Teach Yourself Ballet” from the library and attempted to learn at home with his younger brother.
2018-03-07.headline_main: A Ballet Score? Not Such a Stretch for the Pet Shop Boys

2018-03-07.abstract: Joshua B. Freeman traces the rise of the factory and how it became entwined with Enlightenment ideas of progress.
2018-03-07.snippet: Joshua B. Freeman traces the rise of the factory and how it became entwined with Enlightenment ideas of progress.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: The current president may be completely uninterested in cultivating a number of traditional political skills — among them a sense of discretion and at least the semblance of self-control — but he has an uncanny feel for political symbolism, especially when it comes to the role of manufacturing in the United States. Factory work provides a diminishing share of working-class jobs: There were 43,000 iron and steelworkers last year, compared with almost 2 million hospital and home health aides. But to hear President Trump tell it, the factory workers are the ones who matter most. Just last week, he declared steep tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, tweeting that “trade wars are good, and easy to win.”
2018-03-07.headline_main: In ‘Behemoth,’ Manufacturing Still Looms Large

2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — California and the Trump administration have locked horns from the very first hours of Donald J. Trump’s presidency. But a visit by Attorney General Jeff Sessions to the California capital, Sacramento, on Wednesday produced an unfiltered shouting match that was remarkable even for the long-embattled antagonists, and seemed to be a culmination of fraying relations between the conservative administration and the country’s deepest blue state.

2018-03-07.abstract: In this NBC sitcom, which Ms. Kaling created with Charlie Grandy, a melodramatic boy moves in with the father he’s never met.

2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: Mindy Kaling’s first TV show after “The Mindy Project” is “Champions,” a single-camera comedy she created with Charlie Grandy, a writer and producer for “Mindy.” Beginning on Thursday on NBC, “Champions” has the same constant ticker of references and perky zingers, as well as similar personnel: Anders Holm and Fortune Feimster are both playing versions of their “Mindy” characters.

2018-03-07.abstract: The Netflix-Marvel superhero series, already more focused on female characters than most dramas, was entirely directed and mostly written by women in Season 2.
2018-03-07.snippet: The Netflix-Marvel superhero series, already more focused on female characters than most dramas, was entirely directed and mostly written by women in Season 2.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: The plan to have every episode of the second season of Marvel and Netflix’s “Jessica Jones” directed by women was conceived a year before the Harvey Weinstein revelations. But now that season arrives like a presciently timed herald of the #MeToo-Time’s Up revolution, with 13 female directors and 9 of 13 episodes written or co-written by women. For added emphasis, it begins streaming on Thursday, which is International Women’s Day.
2018-03-07.headline_main: Review: ‘Jessica Jones’ Returns, Well Timed for the Time’s Up Moment

2018-03-07.abstract: Superorganism, Rex Orange County and Clairo are recording chipper, intimate music that’s a wild contrast to the swaggering, anthemic sound of a decade ago.
2018-03-07.snippet: Superorganism, Rex Orange County and Clairo are recording chipper, intimate music that’s a wild contrast to the swaggering, anthemic sound of a decade ago.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: The beginning of the self-titled debut album by Superorganism unfolds one psychedelic smear after the next: fuzzy white noise, throbbing boom-bap drums, heavily processed vocals, squelchy synthesizers. When the vocals come in, they start as a confusing swirl before resolving into sweet melody. It’s like coming up for air after drowning, except the drowning was a dream.
2018-03-07.headline_main: The New Indie Pop: Off-Kilter, Handmade, Whimsical and Emotional

2018-03-07.abstract: In early spring, the partridgeberry cycle begins anew when a few leaves start to sprout from its stem, long buried below winter’s leaf litter.
2018-03-07.snippet: In early spring, the partridgeberry cycle begins anew when a few leaves start to sprout from its stem, long buried below winter’s leaf litter.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: Hikes in early March are all about searching for spring. The coldest, bleakest part of winter is over, days are lengthening, and the ephemeral signs of spring are already evident. Tree buds are swollen, but still mostly shut. Only the hardiest frogs and salamanders are testing the edges of still largely frozen vernal pools. Half submerged in icy water, and calling for mates, spring peepers and wood frogs have particularly poignant voices. Spring is here, but barely.
2018-03-07.headline_main: Spring Awakens! And Partridgeberry Has the Proof

2018-03-07.abstract: Video Room, an Upper East Side fixture since 1979, supplements its movie delivery business with a digital tape transfer service.

2018-03-07.abstract: Who is behind Cynthia Nixon’s possible run for governor? Andrew Cuomo says “probably either the mayor of New York or Vladimir Putin.”

Cuomo, wasted little time in denigrating her as a second-tier celebrity who had been egged on by his longtime Democratic rival, Mayor Bill de Blasio.

2018-03-07.abstract: A species of pitcher plant found in Singapore isn’t very good at dissolving the prey it catches, but it gets nutritional help from worm larvae that live and eat within its maws.
2018-03-07.snippet: A species of pitcher plant found in Singapore isn’t very good at dissolving the prey it catches, but it gets nutritional help from worm larvae that live and eat within its maws.

They appear to be belching, or singing, or screaming out the catch phrase of their cousin in Hollywood — “Feed me Seymour.”

2018-03-07.abstract: Three labels owned by women tell us why working together is the way forward.

2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: One cool thing about fashion — besides the bedazzled footwear, the outlandish cotton candy-colored fur and the enormous purses — is that a lot of very cool women work in it, a fact worth celebrating on Thursday, which is International Women’s Day. Yet when it comes to being the creative director of a grand design house or starting a splashy e-commerce brand, the boys still outnumber the girls. The three companies here are working to change that, applying an approach that stresses collaboration, communication and practicality to create and sell clothes that women crave. Best of all? They are each run by not one woman, but two!

Which is why, when I heard the news that Gary Cohn had resigned as Donald Trump’s top economic adviser, I thought of Red’s (Morgan Freeman’s) somber line: “Every man has his breaking point.”

2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: Christina Hoff Sommers is a self-identified feminist and registered Democrat with a Ph.D. in philosophy and a wicked sense of humor. She is also a woman who says bad things. Things like: Men and women are equal, but there are differences between them. Or: The gender gap in STEM fields isn’t simply the result of sexism. Or: Contrary to received wisdom, the American school system actually favors girls, not boys.

2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: Kalman Aron began drawing pencil and crayon portraits of his family in Latvia when he was 3. A child prodigy, he mounted his first one-boy gallery show when he was 7. He was commissioned to paint the official portrait of the Latvian prime minister when he was 13. He enrolled at an academy of fine arts in Riga, the capital, at 15.

2018-03-07.abstract: In a pattern that has remained unchanged for years, minority children got just 10 percent of the spots at New York City’s specialized high schools.
2018-03-07.snippet: In a pattern that has remained unchanged for years, minority children got just 10 percent of the spots at New York City’s specialized high schools.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: When running for mayor in 2013, Bill de Blasio said the city’s elite high schools had to “reflect the city better.” But according to data released by the education department on Wednesday, black and Latino students made up only 10 percent of those offered spots for next fall at the eight high schools that administer the Specialized High Schools Admissions Test, a percentage that has been essentially unchanged for years.
2018-03-07.headline_main: Elite Schools Make Few Offers to Black and Latino Students

2018-03-07.headline_main: Trump Lawyer Obtained Restraining Order to Silence Stormy Daniels

2018-03-07.abstract: The Texas Senate campaign began with a bang on Wednesday as Senator Ted Cruz mocked Representative Beto O’Rourke for using a childhood nickname.
2018-03-07.snippet: The Texas Senate campaign began with a bang on Wednesday as Senator Ted Cruz mocked Representative Beto O’Rourke for using a childhood nickname.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after the Texas primary, Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, jumped into his general re-election campaign on Wednesday with a quick strike trying to paint his Democratic opponent, Representative Beto O’Rourke, as a Latino-come-lately.
2018-03-07.headline_main: Et Tu, Rafael? Cruz Asks Democratic Rival, Beto O’Rourke, ‘What’s in a Nickname?’

2018-03-07.snippet: Experts say the conversations most likely do not constitute witness tampering, but they show how the president has ignored advice to avoid the appearance of interfering.

2018-03-07.abstract: A new column in the Styles section revisits features from five, 10 and even 20 years ago to measure cultural progress — or lack thereof.
2018-03-07.snippet: A new column in the Styles section revisits features from five, 10 and even 20 years ago to measure cultural progress — or lack thereof.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: A newspaper is by definition about all that is new. But the unique thing about writing lifestyle features for the Styles section of this particular newspaper, as I have done for nearly 14 years, is that our mission is to focus not simply on the new, but on the now — what we think now, how we live now.
2018-03-07.headline_main: Giving Old Trends New Consideration

2018-03-07.abstract: The federal Fish and Wildlife Service will consider allowing some hunters to bring home tusks and hides from certain African countries, overturning an Obama-era prohibition.
2018-03-07.snippet: The federal Fish and Wildlife Service will consider allowing some hunters to bring home tusks and hides from certain African countries, overturning an Obama-era prohibition.
2018-03-07.lead_paragraph: The United States has moved to allow hunters to import big-game trophies, including elephant tusks and lion hides, acquired in certain African countries with approvals granted on an individual basis.

2018-03-07.snippet: Public fights with Mexico, vows to end relations with Cuba and a high-profile exit from a trade deal have signaled a sharp change in America’s approach in the region.

2018-03-08.abstract: A study found that minorities are denied mortgages more than whites, even when accounting for income and other factors.
2018-03-08.snippet: A study found that minorities are denied mortgages more than whites, even when accounting for income and other factors.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: As the Trump administration begins to gut federal enforcement of civil rights laws, minority communities that were targets for predatory home loans before the recession have become vulnerable yet again to mortgage discrimination. This time, many banks are simply writing off communities of color and denying them loans at all.
2018-03-08.headline_main: The Race-Based Mortgage Penalty

2018-03-08.abstract: Ship collisions and entanglements with fishing gear now endanger these whales, once the prey of hunters.
2018-03-08.snippet: Ship collisions and entanglements with fishing gear now endanger these whales, once the prey of hunters.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: GLOUCESTER, Mass. — For the highly endangered North Atlantic right whale, the year has begun badly. One young whale that had become entangled in fishing lines was found dead in January off Virginia. Worse, not a single newborn has yet been spotted by scientists flying over the whale’s calving grounds off Florida and Georgia.
2018-03-08.headline_main: North Atlantic Right Whales Are Near Extinction. We Can Avert It.

2018-03-08.abstract: Nothing is “artificial” about this technology. It is made by us, for us.
2018-03-08.snippet: Nothing is “artificial” about this technology. It is made by us, for us.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: For a field that was not well known outside of academia a decade ago, artificial intelligence has grown dizzyingly fast. Tech companies from Silicon Valley to Beijing are betting everything on it, venture capitalists are pouring billions into research and development, and start-ups are being created on what seems like a daily basis. If our era is the next Industrial Revolution, as many claim, A.I. is surely one of its driving forces.
2018-03-08.headline_main: How to Make A.I. That’s Good for People

2018-03-08.abstract: As the British weekly ceases its print publication, a look back at some of the stars (and almost-stars) it was known for supporting.
2018-03-08.snippet: As the British weekly ceases its print publication, a look back at some of the stars (and almost-stars) it was known for supporting.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: When 1976 began, the British weekly New Musical Express (NME) was still putting Bad Company and Small Faces on its cover. That fall, the publication inched into the world of punk with two Sex Pistols issues — placing Rod Stewart in between, just to be cautious — and discovered its niche: hyping a colorful rock band, preferably British, ideally male, and even if it wasn’t very good. If the photos were fun and the quotes were provocative, who cared? There would always be another issue in six days.
2018-03-08.headline_main: 5 Bands the NME Lovingly, Relentlessly Championed

2018-03-08.abstract: Texas primary results show that 2018 will not be a Democratic cakewalk.
2018-03-08.snippet: Texas primary results show that 2018 will not be a Democratic cakewalk.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: The prevailing wisdom suggests that there will be a Democratic wave election in 2018. In a manner that suggests that little was learned from the 2016 primary or general elections, pundits and analysts seem so committed to this narrative that they promote it even when the data point in the other direction.
2018-03-08.headline_main: About That Blue Wave …

2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Adam Rippon became a for-real famous person in America in under a month. The 28-year-old figure skater arrived home from the Winter Olympics with a bronze medal in the figure skating team event, went on “The Ellen DeGeneres Show,” had photo shoots with magazines including InStyle and Rolling Stone, went to the Oscars in an S-and-M-themed tuxedo that got rave reviews, and then came to New York City for stops at Vanity Fair and BuzzFeed and Bravo.

2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: The construction cranes that pierce the Auckland skyline are a visual indication of the growth New Zealand’s largest city is experiencing. Close to one-third of New Zealand’s estimated 4.5 million population lives in Auckland, a geographically blessed — and traffic-cursed — city spread over at least 50 volcanic cones on a North Island neck of land between two large harbors. The emerging Wynyard Quarter on the western waterfront is home to a new theater, a park where movies are projected onto the side of a former cement silo in the Southern Hemisphere summer and several restaurants. Auckland’s personality, like New Zealand’s, is laid-back and outdoorsy, but its sophistication shines in its expanding art scene, thriving fashion industry and a new generation of chefs embracing native ingredients.
2018-03-08.headline_main: 36 Hours in Auckland

2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Next week’s special congressional election in southwestern Pennsylvania will test whether, deep in Trump country, union support can help elect a Democrat running on a middle-class economic agenda. A victory would remind Democrats of the electoral power of organized labor. Even though it has relied on unions’ electoral muscle for nearly a century, the party has often failed to shore up labor’s diminishing strength. Our research demonstrates what an enormous electoral mistake that has been.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Right-to-Work Laws Have Devastated Unions — and Democrats

2018-03-08.abstract: The Klamath have joined with other Native American tribes to oppose a gas pipeline they say would threaten the Klamath River.
2018-03-08.snippet: The Klamath have joined with other Native American tribes to oppose a gas pipeline they say would threaten the Klamath River.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: KLAMATH FALLS, Ore. — Each spring and fall in the old days, Chinook salmon swam up the Klamath River, crossing the Cascade Mountains, to Upper Klamath Lake, 4,000 feet above sea level. For millenniums, the Klamath, Modoc and Yahooskin Band of Snake Indians fished salmon from the lake and the river. The Klamath had agreements with the downriver tribes — the Karuk, Hoopa and Yurok among them — to let fish pass so that some could swim all the way back to their spawning grounds.
2018-03-08.headline_main: The Next Standing Rock? A Pipeline Battle Looms in Oregon

2018-03-08.abstract: Yes, he pushed Lyndon Johnson out of the 1968 race. But he was an aloof, uninspiring candidate.
2018-03-08.snippet: Yes, he pushed Lyndon Johnson out of the 1968 race. But he was an aloof, uninspiring candidate.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago next week, Senator Eugene McCarthy of Minnesota scored a near-upset in New Hampshire’s Democratic presidential primary, setting in motion Lyndon Johnson’s announcement, three weeks later, that he would “not seek, and I will not accept, the nomination of my party for another term as your president.” It was a jaw-dropping series of events, one that gave McCarthy a near-mythic status in American political history.
2018-03-08.headline_main: The Myth of Eugene McCarthy

2018-03-08.abstract: This film, from the Chilean director Gustavo Letelier, is oddly enticing in its experimental awkwardness.
2018-03-08.snippet: This film, from the Chilean director Gustavo Letelier, is oddly enticing in its experimental awkwardness.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: “Your love is going away like water in the fingers,” complains Renato (Ricardo Herrera) to his lover, Ivan (Pablo Sotomayor Prat), near the beginning of “Shining Moon” (“El Destello de la Luna”), the new film from the Chilean director Gustavo Letelier. Though both are underemployed actors, Renato is clearly the more theatrical of the two: Fond of declamatory monologues and carefully calibrated gestures, he’s a man who seeks the light as instinctively as any newly liberated soul.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: In ‘Shining Moon,’ Two Gay Chilean Actors Confront the Past

2018-03-08.abstract: The director Hong Sang-soo shows us the less-than-glamorous side of a famous beach town.
2018-03-08.snippet: The director Hong Sang-soo shows us the less-than-glamorous side of a famous beach town.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Since early in his career, the South Korean director Hong Sang-soo has told stories about the frustrated and frustrating love lives of movie people. They’re mostly male, mostly screenwriters or directors, and they’re mostly very heavy drinkers. Although they’re more confused than is considered healthy even when they’re sober. One thing about these characters is that you’d never know they worked in movies if they didn’t mention it in the dialogue. Mr. Hong’s camera almost never depicts movie sets.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: In ‘Claire’s Camera,’ Isabelle Huppert Plays a Cannes Newbie

2018-03-08.abstract: A second documentary about Andy Goldsworthy is concerned with how time changes his art — and him.
2018-03-08.snippet: A second documentary about Andy Goldsworthy is concerned with how time changes his art — and him.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: On the basis of “Leaning Into the Wind,” when it rains, the British artist Andy Goldsworthy immediately drops to the ground and lets the water outline his body. He describes two ways of approaching the world: “You can walk on the path, or you can walk through the hedge.” It’s almost a given that this documentary about his ephemeral, nature-based art will eventually show him trudging through a hedge, oblivious to or uninterested in the perfectly functional sidewalk next to it.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: In ‘Leaning Into the Wind — Andy Goldsworthy,’ an Artist Grapples (Again) With Time

2018-03-08.abstract: Charlotte Rampling is transfixing as a woman suffering for her husband’s crime in this quietly stressful film.
2018-03-08.snippet: Charlotte Rampling is transfixing as a woman suffering for her husband’s crime in this quietly stressful film.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: The face is everything. From the very first shot, tight and merciless, Charlotte Rampling’s pale, stricken countenance sets the tone of “Hannah” and dominates virtually every moment thereafter. By the end, we feel so wrung out it takes a second or two to realize that very little has happened.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: ‘Hannah’ Presents a Woman Undone

2018-03-08.abstract: Itzhak Perlman makes beautiful music in this documentary by Alison Chernick.
2018-03-08.snippet: Itzhak Perlman makes beautiful music in this documentary by Alison Chernick.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Alison Chernick’s documentary is a fond portrait of the violinist Itzhak Perlman. He makes “garbage-pail soup” for Alan Alda; plays the national anthem for a Mets game; collaborates, jovially and seemingly scrubbed of ego, with other musicians. Most important, he plays, filling the film with the yearning strains of his instrument.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: ‘Itzhak,’ the Man and the Musician

2018-03-08.abstract: “The Forgiven” is heavy-handed from its opening moments through its end credits.
2018-03-08.snippet: “The Forgiven” is heavy-handed from its opening moments through its end credits.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: The director Roland Joffé (who made “The Killing Fields,” about Pol Pot’s slaughter in Cambodia, and “The Mission,” a tale of 18th-century colonialism with pronounced allegorical accents) is not known for a light touch. Here, adapting a play by Michael Ashton, he makes South Africa’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission of the 1990s his subject, and “The Forgiven” is heavy-handed from its early texts explaining apartheid through its end credits.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: In ‘The Forgiven,’ Forest Whitaker as Archbishop Desmond Tutu

2018-03-08.abstract: A Republican polling surge has faded. It’s another example of how seeming political shifts have proved ephemeral.
2018-03-08.snippet: A Republican polling surge has faded. It’s another example of how seeming political shifts have proved ephemeral.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: There are still 243 days until the midterm elections. There’s plenty of time for events to reshape the race for control of Congress.
2018-03-08.headline_main: News Changes Fast, but Polls Keep Snapping Back Into Place

2018-03-08.abstract: Helen Mirren and Donald Sutherland star as a couple, facing illnesses, who take their 1975 Winnebago and set out for Key West, Fla.
2018-03-08.snippet: Helen Mirren and Donald Sutherland star as a couple, facing illnesses, who take their 1975 Winnebago and set out for Key West, Fla.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: “The Leisure Seeker,” the first English-language feature from the Italian director Paolo Virzì, stars Helen Mirren and Donald Sutherland as a couple who skip town in a 1975 Winnebago, heading from Wellesley, Mass., to Florida, without giving notice to anyone, including their grown children. Ella (Ms. Mirren) plans to take John (Mr. Sutherland), an expert on Ernest Hemingway, to the Hemingway Home in Key West.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: On the Road for a Last Taste of Freedom in ‘The Leisure Seeker’

2018-03-08.abstract: President Trump has backed trade restrictions for much of his public life, but his tariff orders have some wiggle room.
2018-03-08.snippet: President Trump has backed trade restrictions for much of his public life, but his tariff orders have some wiggle room.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. Here’s what we’re watching:
2018-03-08.headline_main: The Leeway in President Trump’s Tariff Order: DealBook Briefing

2018-03-08.abstract: Despite a crackdown during the National People’s Congress, opposition is bubbling up as President Xi Jinping moves to abolish term limits.
2018-03-08.snippet: Despite a crackdown during the National People’s Congress, opposition is bubbling up as President Xi Jinping moves to abolish term limits.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In the lofty chambers of the Great Hall of the People, delegate after delegate to China’s legislative body brushed aside questions this week about the constitutional change on the table that could extend Xi Jinping’s presidency.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Murmurings of Dissent Upset China’s Script for Xi’s Power Grab

2018-03-08.abstract: Part of a male quartet from Paul Taylor’s “Cloven Kingdom,” which flickers between grace and ferocity as men and women battle their true natures
2018-03-08.snippet: Part of a male quartet from Paul Taylor’s “Cloven Kingdom,” which flickers between grace and ferocity as men and women battle their true natures
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.
2018-03-08.headline_main: The Animal Underneath

2018-03-08.abstract: The new smartphone is packed with gimmicky new features like a personal emoji creator. Don’t be surprised if getting used to those emoji takes what a Samsung executive called “an adjustment period.”
2018-03-08.snippet: The new smartphone is packed with gimmicky new features like a personal emoji creator. Don’t be surprised if getting used to those emoji takes what a Samsung executive called “an adjustment period.”
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know about Samsung’s newest flagship smartphone, the Galaxy S9, in five words: The device plays it safe.
2018-03-08.headline_main: A Review of the Samsung Galaxy S9, in Emoji

2018-03-08.abstract: There was a keen awareness of a sense of urgency and a shift on issues of gender parity, women’s treatment in the workplace and sexual dynamics.
2018-03-08.snippet: There was a keen awareness of a sense of urgency and a shift on issues of gender parity, women’s treatment in the workplace and sexual dynamics.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: ROME — In the era of #MeToo and Time’s Up, International Women’s Day arrived on Thursday with a renewed sense of urgency.
2018-03-08.headline_main: International Women’s Day 2018: Beyond #MeToo, With Pride, Protests and Pressure

2018-03-08.abstract: Hair loss, mouth ulcers, kidney disease, skin rashes, mental fog — the symptoms of lupus are mysterious, diverse and unique to each person. Six people discuss a life with lupus.
2018-03-08.snippet: Hair loss, mouth ulcers, kidney disease, skin rashes, mental fog — the symptoms of lupus are mysterious, diverse and unique to each person. Six people discuss a life with lupus.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Hair loss, mouth ulcers, kidney disease, skin rashes, mental fog — the symptoms of lupus are mysterious, diverse and unique to each person. Six people discuss a life with lupus.

2018-03-08.snippet: The authorities prevented Maryam Mombeini, the widow of an environmental campaigner who the authorities say hanged himself, from boarding an international flight.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The wife of Kavous Seyed Emami, the Iranian-Canadian environmentalist who died in an Iranian jail after being accused of spying, was barred from leaving the country on Thursday, her sons said.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Wife of Iranian-Canadian Who Died in Jail Is Barred from Leaving Iran

2018-03-08.abstract: The team’s Legion of Boom defense appears on its way to oblivion without having gotten enough credit for just how dominant it was.
2018-03-08.snippet: The team’s Legion of Boom defense appears on its way to oblivion without having gotten enough credit for just how dominant it was.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: It was one of the most important plays for one of the greatest defenses in N.F.L. history, but it has been all but forgotten because of what happened afterward.
2018-03-08.headline_main: In Seattle, a Seahawks Defense That Flowed Together Drifts Apart

2018-03-08.abstract: Several troubleshooting tools included in Windows 10 can help revive your system if it just won’t work properly.

2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Q. Can you explain just what a recovery drive will do as opposed to a system restore point or a recovery image? How do these features differ from Reset PC? If my Windows 10 Surface Book crashes, which feature do I try first?
2018-03-08.headline_main: Windows 10: When to Restore, Reset or Recover
