2018-03-08.snippet: Thursday: Backlash against Attorney General Jeff Sessions’s visit, San Francisco is sinking, and wild turkeys stir divisions in the East Bay.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Good morning.
2018-03-08.headline_main: California Today: Peter Thiel Is Leaving Silicon Valley. Will Others?

2018-03-08.abstract: Historically, these distant conflicts have been difficult to analyze. But new technologies allow us to investigate them in close to real time.
2018-03-08.snippet: Historically, these distant conflicts have been difficult to analyze. But new technologies allow us to investigate them in close to real time.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: In mid-February a source in the human rights community told me that villages in a remote region of the Democratic Republic of Congo were being burned amid a renewal of communal fighting. People fleeing the violence told aid workers of arson attacks.
2018-03-08.headline_main: How We Identified Burned Villages in the Democratic Republic of Congo

2018-03-08.abstract: Humans are hard-wired to run from pain, so you may want to sell stocks when markets gyrate. But before you do that, try physical human contact instead.
2018-03-08.snippet: Humans are hard-wired to run from pain, so you may want to sell stocks when markets gyrate. But before you do that, try physical human contact instead.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: If you’re worried about the stock market, find someone to give you a hug.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Jittery From Stock Market Volatility? Don’t Run. Just Hug.

2018-03-08.abstract: With so many new buildings coming on the market, developers are offering enticements like parking spots and custom closets to sell their last units.
2018-03-08.snippet: With so many new buildings coming on the market, developers are offering enticements like parking spots and custom closets to sell their last units.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: It is, by most measures, a standard-issue parking space, albeit one tucked under the Sterling Mason, a handsome building designed by the architect Morris Adjmi in TriBeCa. But the 12-by-24-foot spot below the lobby may well be the key to finally securing a buyer for the $15.5 million Penthouse C, the last unsold condominium in the 32-unit building.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Condos With Extras on the Side

2018-03-08.abstract: The Sooners and their exciting freshman guard are in jeopardy of missing the N.C.A.A. tournament, something unthinkable in January.
2018-03-08.snippet: The Sooners and their exciting freshman guard are in jeopardy of missing the N.C.A.A. tournament, something unthinkable in January.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Oklahoma and its exciting freshman guard, Trae Young, looked to be the most intriguing team in N.C.A.A. men’s basketball this season, a serious candidate for the N.C.A.A. tournament Final Four.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Collapse Leaves Trae Young and Oklahoma Awaiting N.C.A.A. Fate

2018-03-08.abstract: David Oyelowo plays an innocent who gets played by the likes of Charlize Theron and Joel Edgerton in this Tarantino knockoff.
2018-03-08.snippet: David Oyelowo plays an innocent who gets played by the likes of Charlize Theron and Joel Edgerton in this Tarantino knockoff.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Harold Soyinka, a midlevel executive at a Chicago pharmaceutical company, is originally from Nigeria. This puts someone in mind of those princely email swindles. It’s a pretty weak joke (made worse by the fact that Harold says an uncle of his made a fortune that way) and also an example of what passes for irony in “Gringo,” a new movie directed by Nash Edgerton from a screenplay by Anthony Tambakis and Matthew Stone. Harold, you see, is a perfect sucker, an innocent whose trusting good nature makes him an easy target for grifters, scammers and liars.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: The Caper-Comedy ‘Gringo’ Is Staler Than Yesterday’s Tortillas

2018-03-08.abstract: Mr. Cumming talks about his new series and playing network TV’s first gay lead in an hourlong drama.
2018-03-08.snippet: Mr. Cumming talks about his new series and playing network TV’s first gay lead in an hourlong drama.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Alan Cumming — actor, author, irrepressible provocateur — rarely shies away from expressing his desires, whether in choosing his roles (the pansexual M.C. in “Cabaret,” the fluidly dallying husband in “The Anniversary Party”) or identifying as bisexual (once married to a woman, he is now married to a man). And he hopes his latest character will be just as bold.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Alan Cumming Helps CBS Unfurl Its Rainbow Flag With ‘Instinct’

2018-03-08.abstract: Mitzi Angel, the publisher of Faber & Faber in London, will take over at FSG from Jonathan Galassi, who will remain as president.
2018-03-08.snippet: Mitzi Angel, the publisher of Faber & Faber in London, will take over at FSG from Jonathan Galassi, who will remain as president.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: In the preface to his novel “Muse,” an affectionate sendup of the publishing industry, Jonathan Galassi pines for a bygone era when “literature was life” and “books were revered, hoarded, collected.”
2018-03-08.headline_main: A New Publisher for Farrar, Straus & Giroux

2018-03-08.abstract: Mary Anne Hobbs, who worked at the British music newspaper in its heyday, reflects on what we’ll miss when the title stops publishing in print.
2018-03-08.snippet: Mary Anne Hobbs, who worked at the British music newspaper in its heyday, reflects on what we’ll miss when the title stops publishing in print.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — “Nirvana. You probably barely recognize the name, but by the time this page is ink on your fingertips, Nirvana will have sold 1,000,000 copies of their new LP.”
2018-03-08.headline_main: The NME Bows Out of Print. We’ll Miss the Inky Fingers.

2018-03-08.abstract: Florida lawmakers overwhelmingly passed a bill to keep the state on daylight saving time year-round. The only problem: They don’t have the authority to do that.
2018-03-08.snippet: Florida lawmakers overwhelmingly passed a bill to keep the state on daylight saving time year-round. The only problem: They don’t have the authority to do that.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Few traditions are more maligned than the semiannual switch between standard time and daylight saving time.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Year-Round Daylight Saving Time? Florida Says Yes, but It’s Not So Simple

2018-03-08.abstract: With art by Tracey Emin and Puppies Puppies, Tiffany Zabludowicz, 25, keeps things contemporary but makes space for a Jean Prouvé desk, too.
2018-03-08.snippet: With art by Tracey Emin and Puppies Puppies, Tiffany Zabludowicz, 25, keeps things contemporary but makes space for a Jean Prouvé desk, too.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Tiffany Zabludowicz has so much art in her two-bedroom SoHo apartment that a perfectly braided loaf of bread on her kitchen counter is immediately suspect: Is that a Claes Oldenburg-style sculpture of a challah, or the thing itself?
2018-03-08.headline_main: A Young Collector Continues the Family Tradition in SoHo

2018-03-08.abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
2018-03-08.snippet: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Relax. Take a deep breath. In the immortal words of Queen Elsa, let it go. If there’s a theme to this week’s recommended titles, it might be that things aren’t as hopeless as you think. From Lauren Slater’s “Blue Dreams,” about pharmaceutical efforts to battle depression, to Steven Pinker’s “Enlightenment Now” and Gregg Easterbrook’s “It’s Better Than It Looks,” both of which marshal statistics to argue that life today is pretty O.K., to a study of happiness in old age and a debut novel that challenges Western views of mental illness, we’ve got well-being on the mind. You’ll also find a couple of memoirs — one from a former Marine, the other from a former denizen of Tokyo’s avant-garde — and, for readers determined to wallow in the gloom, a look at America’s intractable and increasing political divide. What, us worry?
2018-03-08.headline_main: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week

2018-03-08.abstract: Sergei Skripal and his daughter remain unconscious. But Britain is not yet apportioning blame for what a senior official called the “brazen and reckless” assault.
2018-03-08.snippet: Sergei Skripal and his daughter remain unconscious. But Britain is not yet apportioning blame for what a senior official called the “brazen and reckless” assault.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The former Russian spy Sergei V. Skripal and his daughter, Yulia Skripal, remain unconscious and are in critical but stable condition, Britain’s home secretary, Amber Rudd, told lawmakers on Thursday, adding that it was too early to apportion blame for a “brazen and reckless” attack involving a nerve agent.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Ex-Russian Spy ‘Stable’ After Nerve Agent Attack in U.K.

2018-03-08.abstract: Armando Iannucci’s movie is a very funny comedy about life, death and totalitarianism, and it features a superb Steve Buscemi as Khrushchev.
2018-03-08.snippet: Armando Iannucci’s movie is a very funny comedy about life, death and totalitarianism, and it features a superb Steve Buscemi as Khrushchev.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: The comedy of cruelty is rarely funnier or more brutal than when it comes from Armando Iannucci, a virtuoso of political evisceration. A comic talent who should be household famous, he is best known for “Veep,” the HBO series about Washington politics that was a satire when it first hit in 2012 but now seems like a reality show. He also directed the movie “In the Loop,” an aptly obscene burlesque about the run-up to the Iraq War. He only seems to have abandoned contemporary politics in his latest, “The Death of Stalin,” an eccentric comic shocker about a strong man and his world of ashes and blood.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: The Slapstick Horror of ‘The Death of Stalin’

2018-03-08.abstract: A recent announcement about funding priorities for a major family planning program hints at retrograde thinking about contraception.
2018-03-08.snippet: A recent announcement about funding priorities for a major family planning program hints at retrograde thinking about contraception.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Women’s progress in America has been inextricably tied to the availability of birth control. Landmark Supreme Court decisions in 1965 and 1972 recognizing a constitutional right to contraception made it more likely that women went to college, entered the work force and found economic stability. That’s all because they were better able to choose when, or whether, to have children.
2018-03-08.headline_main: The Trump Administration’s Backward Attitude Toward Birth Control

2018-03-08.abstract: This style of sparkling wine, perhaps the very first, had largely died out. But natural wine producers embraced it, and it has gained popularity.
2018-03-08.snippet: This style of sparkling wine, perhaps the very first, had largely died out. But natural wine producers embraced it, and it has gained popularity.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Don’t call pétillant naturel the new bubbly in town. Don’t call it “the new rosé,” as Eater.com did in 2016 in an effort to encapsulate its trendiness. In fact, don’t call it the new anything.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Bubbles, With Joy: Pétillant Naturel’s Triumphant Return

2018-03-08.abstract: A reader’s boyfriend insists on footing the bill, but she wants to treat sometimes.
2018-03-08.snippet: A reader’s boyfriend insists on footing the bill, but she wants to treat sometimes.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: My wonderful boyfriend (of one year) won’t let me pay for anything! We’re in our mid-20s. He refuses to split checks and never lets me treat him. He makes more money than I do, but I can afford to pay half. It feels old-fashioned and weirdly paternalistic that he’s so insistent about paying. But what bothers me most is that I feel indebted. When I bring it up, he laughs and tells me “not to take it that way.” I don’t push these conversations very hard, but I’m getting annoyed. What do I do?
2018-03-08.headline_main: Why Can’t a Modern Woman Pay (at Least) Half?

2018-03-08.abstract: Promised a new apartment on the Lower East Side 50 years ago, David Santiago finally claimed it, but he could enjoy it only briefly before his death this month.
2018-03-08.snippet: Promised a new apartment on the Lower East Side 50 years ago, David Santiago finally claimed it, but he could enjoy it only briefly before his death this month.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: It was a homecoming party 50 years in the making.
2018-03-08.headline_main: A Joyful Homecoming Cut Short

2018-03-08.abstract: Five standout Taylor dancers talk about their careers in the company and working for a modern master who is still making dances at 87.
2018-03-08.snippet: Five standout Taylor dancers talk about their careers in the company and working for a modern master who is still making dances at 87.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Being a member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company is a binding kind of love. It’s a communal enterprise in which working together brings Mr. Taylor’s dances to life. But individuality is important. What happens when a dancer — and no two are alike — is united with Mr. Taylor’s choreography?
2018-03-08.headline_main: Get to Know the Colors on Paul Taylor’s Palette

2018-03-08.abstract: With her miniature laboratory in tow, a doctoral student is always on the hunt for pigeons, living or dead.
2018-03-08.snippet: With her miniature laboratory in tow, a doctoral student is always on the hunt for pigeons, living or dead.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: “This is my lab,” said Elizabeth Carlen, as she started her car with a blast of rap music springing from the speakers.
2018-03-08.headline_main: The Pigeon Stalker

2018-03-08.abstract: In this misfire, two teenage ciphers watch old movies, plot a crime and peer into the heart of murkiness.
2018-03-08.snippet: In this misfire, two teenage ciphers watch old movies, plot a crime and peer into the heart of murkiness.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: “Thoroughbreds” opens on an ominous, murkily lit scene — a girl, a horse and a worryingly sharp knife — that telegraphs just how ugly things are going to get in this movie. You learn in short order that the horse is a goner, and it isn’t long into this slick, shallow movie that you wish the girl, Amanda (Olivia Cooke), was, too. This is no fault of Ms. Cooke, an appealing performer (she was the girl in “Me and Earl and the Dying Girl”). She and her equally likable co-star, Anya Taylor-Joy (“The Witch”), have been burdened with giving their matching ciphers flesh and a reason for us to watch.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Review: Meet the Peewee Nihilists of ‘Thoroughbreds’

2018-03-08.abstract: Two leaders of Britain First were found guilty of religiously aggravated harassment. They gained notoriety when President Trump shared their videos.
2018-03-08.snippet: Two leaders of Britain First were found guilty of religiously aggravated harassment. They gained notoriety when President Trump shared their videos.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The leaders of an anti-Muslim extremist group in Britain have been found guilty of hate crimes and sentenced to prison, months after they drew international attention for helping President Trump get entangled in a diplomatic dispute with British leaders.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Anti-Muslim Extremists Retweeted by Trump Are Convicted of Hate Crimes

2018-03-08.abstract: What is life like for an 8-year-old boy in a coastal Greenland village? Watch a five-minute film that touches on themes of identity and coming of age.
2018-03-08.snippet: What is life like for an 8-year-old boy in a coastal Greenland village? Watch a five-minute film that touches on themes of identity and coming of age.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: In “Arctic Boyhood,” a five-minute film that touches on themes of identity and coming of age, Samuel Collardey explores the lives of the coastal inhabitants of Greenland’s Tasiilaq villages, and in particular, of Asser Boassen, an 8-year-old Tunumiit boy who wants to become a hunter.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Teaching With: ‘Arctic Boyhood’

2018-03-08.abstract: Wendell Steavenson, who felt intrusive when talking to victims of horrific attacks, found freedom in writing her novel, “Paris Metro.”
2018-03-08.snippet: Wendell Steavenson, who felt intrusive when talking to victims of horrific attacks, found freedom in writing her novel, “Paris Metro.”
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Friday, Nov. 13, 2015, Wendell Steavenson, the war reporter and food writer, was in Tbilisi, Georgia, to film an episode of Anthony Bourdain’s foodie travel series “Parts Unknown.” She’d gone to bed early.

2018-03-08.abstract: Brave the winter weather for Piers 92/94 in Manhattan, and you’ll find a great mix of works from Cuba, Norway, the Netherlands and more.
2018-03-08.snippet: Brave the winter weather for Piers 92/94 in Manhattan, and you’ll find a great mix of works from Cuba, Norway, the Netherlands and more.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: The Armory Show, one of the city’s top fairs for 20th- and 21st-century art, had a shake-up in the last year: one director replaced following accusations of sexual harassment, and a shift in focus under its new director, Nicole Berry. There is a notable drive toward streamlining, with fewer galleries this year — a total of 198 from 31 countries at Piers 92/94, the contiguous exhibition space. The timeline is being tightened, as well, to create less of a divide between the past and the present, between post-World War II art (usually found on the sleepier Pier 92) and newer work. It’s a smart move, since much “historical” art from the 1950s, ’60s and ’70s is now being shown in contemporary galleries anyway.
2018-03-08.headline_main: 30 Must-See Artists at the Armory Show

2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: If, like me, you find the full-tilt art fairs a little overwhelming, the formally ambitious but modestly scaled Independent is a godsend. With just 54 exhibits, many of them solo presentations, arranged over four spacious floors at Spring Studios in TriBeCa, it’s like a leisurely all-star game: It’s not exactly representative of the year in art, perhaps, but it feels as if it ought to be.
2018-03-08.headline_main: The Don’t-Misses at Independent and NADA

2018-03-08.abstract: The conceptual designer's devotees reflect on his legacy and his landmark fall/winter 2000 collection.
2018-03-08.snippet: The conceptual designer's devotees reflect on his legacy and his landmark fall/winter 2000 collection.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: Though he left his eponymous label nearly a decade ago, there are few designers as influential today as Martin Margiela. While he aspired to be invisible — to the point of refusing to be photographed and conducting all interviews by fax or email — Margiela’s impact is writ large on the contemporary fashion landscape. So many of his innovations — once radical — have become accepted norms in the industry (his deconstructed tailoring, his championing of recycling and his pioneering of the see-now buy-now model, to name but a few). Brands as diverse as Vetements, Marques’Almeida and The Row continually mine his archive for inspiration. The conceptual Belgian designer is being celebrated in two separate exhibitions in Paris this month: a retrospective at the Palais Galliera, which examines his career until he retired in 2009, and another at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs, which premiered in Antwerp last year and catalogs his six-year tenure designing for Hermès.
2018-03-08.headline_main: 7 Martin Margiela Fans and Collaborators Remember His Most Radical Show

Azar II, the secretary of health and human services, said Thursday that doctors and hospitals should tell patients how much their care would cost before patients received treatment. And if they do not do so voluntarily, he said, the government may use its leverage to force them to disclose the information.
2018-03-08.headline_main: Health Officials Assail ‘Pricing Schemes’ That Gouge Patients

2018-03-08.abstract: Christopher Bailey and Carolina Herrera had big send-offs, Gucci gave us dragon puppies — and Queen Elizabeth went to a fashion show.
2018-03-08.snippet: Christopher Bailey and Carolina Herrera had big send-offs, Gucci gave us dragon puppies — and Queen Elizabeth went to a fashion show.
2018-03-08.lead_paragraph: New York is not a fashion week city traditionally known for its sets and productions. Aside from Marc Jacobs — who became known for his elaborate collection tableau before he stripped everything away except the audience’s folding chairs — the focus is typically on the product, not the performance. However, this season Raf Simons at Calvin Klein and Kerby Jean-Raymond of Pyer Moss changed all that. Simons trucked in 50,000 gallons of popcorn from Chicago and filled the floor of the old American Stock Exchange building with the stuff, which piled up in drifts along the sides of four rickety barns, crunched under guests’s feet, and stuck to models’ shoes and prairie-dress-meets-hazmat-suits they wore down the runway. The effect was like a B-movie nuclear winter in a dream western town.
2018-03-08.headline_main: The Top 10 Moments of Fashion Month

But the chances of heading off this policy disaster are small, because this is a quintessential example of Trump being Trump.

2018-03-09.abstract: When Campbell Robertson set out to find why black worshipers were leaving white-majority churches, he recalled the little Baptist church he grew up in.
2018-03-09.snippet: When Campbell Robertson set out to find why black worshipers were leaving white-majority churches, he recalled the little Baptist church he grew up in.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: I grew up in a little Baptist church in small-town Alabama. The Baptist part is inherited, like baldness or dimples: Both of my grandfathers and three of my uncles were Baptist preachers, and my parents met as graduate students at Southern Baptist Theological Seminary. Genes aside, the church — plastic chairs, pilling carpet and grape juice for communion — was the organizing institution of my childhood, where I met my closest friends and most of the significant adults in my life.
2018-03-09.headline_main: At the Crossroads of Church and Race, a Reporter Glimpses His Childhood

And what happened? Who won the election in ’68? Richard Nixon.”

2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: At the last survey of new photography at the Museum of Modern Art two years ago, the atmosphere was so self-referential and hermetic that a visitor panted for oxygen. Often, the photos were images of images, taken off a computer screen or digitally created in the studio. It seemed as if photography, which continued to engage with the world after modernist painting and literature turned inward, had finally crumpled into solipsism.

The payment was to stop Daniels from speaking out about an alleged affair she’d had with Trump shortly after Melania Trump, his third wife, gave birth to their son, Barron.

2018-03-09.snippet: When the United States is nowhere, silent, AWOL, despots get to do their worst.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: After Aleppo, now comes the agony of Eastern Ghouta. This suburb of Damascus, the last rebel-held enclave close to the Syrian capital, is bombarded by Bashar al-Assad’s forces for weeks on end, with Russian air support. More than 900 people, including many children, are killed. Hospitals are targeted in what François Delattre, the French ambassador to the United Nations, has called “a siege worthy of the Middle Ages.” Pregnant women bleed to death. Some 400,000 people are trapped.
2018-03-09.headline_main: Trump’s World and the Retreat of Shame

2018-03-09.abstract: The bass, a famed Falstaff and Boris Godunov, reflects on half a century of opera as he prepares for one of his final Met performances.
2018-03-09.snippet: The bass, a famed Falstaff and Boris Godunov, reflects on half a century of opera as he prepares for one of his final Met performances.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: The voice is a fragile thing, and few singers end up with 50-year careers at the Metropolitan Opera. The bass Paul Plishka is one of them. He has sung dozens of small comprimario parts — the character roles of opera — but also starred in Mussorgsky’s “Boris Godunov” and Verdi’s “Falstaff.” Some roles, including Raimondo, the chaplain in Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor,” he has done at the Met more than anyone else. He was onstage for the first “Live From the Metropolitan Opera” telecast and the company debuts of both Luciano Pavarotti and Plácido Domingo, who will celebrate his own 50th anniversary next season.
2018-03-09.headline_main: After 50 Years at the Met Opera, Paul Plishka Retires (Again)

2018-03-09.snippet: The deaths of two children crossing a busy street in Brooklyn suggest that the war on pedestrian fatalities is really a war against unfit motorists.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: The picture that circulated of Dorothy Bruns after her speeding white Volvo passed through a red light, leaving two children dead in a busy intersection in Brooklyn on Monday, is what initially sparked the rage. Shown on a gurney, sitting upright, an open purse on her lap, her long hair tucked into her black parka, she is texting without any suggestion of misery or even agitation, as if she were simply letting a friend know that she was going to be late for tennis.

2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. But this week, The Times introduced “Overlooked,” a new project to publish the stories of people who left indelible marks on the world, but whose obituaries were never written. In honor of International Women’s Day on March 8, the feature begins with 15 women. The collection will be added to each week, and will expand the lens beyond women as it becomes a regular feature.

2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Last month, when I returned to Madeleine L’Engle’s novel “A Wrinkle in Time,” more than 35 years after I first read it, I was taken aback. The intricate plot was as I remembered: The gangly, genius teenager Meg Murry, her younger brother, Charles Wallace, and her friend Calvin O’Keefe still travel through time and space by way of a tesseract, a fifth-dimensional phenomenon, to rescue her father from the evil IT, a disembodied brain that demands conformity from all who surround it.
2018-03-09.headline_main: I Saw Myself in ‘A Wrinkle in Time.’ But I Had to Work Hard.

2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: LONDON — At least four times a year, Christie’s, Phillips and Sotheby’s hold evening auctions of high-end contemporary art in New York and London. This week, it was London’s turn. The auctions feature works by a predictable cast of prestigious names, marketed across the world to the select group of wealthy individuals who covet and can afford blue-chip 20th- and 21st-century art.
2018-03-09.headline_main: London Auctions Play It Safe With the Tried, the Trusted and the Dead

2018-03-09.abstract: “If it made us laugh, it went in the book,” Brian Selznick and David Serlin said, describing how they dreamed up the outrageous antics of “Baby Monkey, Private Eye.”
2018-03-09.snippet: “If it made us laugh, it went in the book,” Brian Selznick and David Serlin said, describing how they dreamed up the outrageous antics of “Baby Monkey, Private Eye.”
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: MURDER, SHE BAKED: Want some crime to go with that croissant? “Raspberry Danish Murder” — the 22nd volume in Joanne Fluke’s culinary cozy series — debuts on the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 6, following earlier installments like “Cherry Cheesecake Murder,” “Cinnamon Roll Murder” and “Strawberry Shortcake Murder.” The books, which star a small-town baker-turned-sleuth, all feature recipes. Fluke picks a sweet treat first and then builds the plot of the book around it. “Obviously, I would never do a book called ‘Baked Alaska Murder’ since making a baked alaska is certainly not a simple thing to do,” she says. “And I’d never do ‘Prune Danish Murder’ because who thinks a recipe with prunes in it sounds tasty?”
2018-03-09.headline_main: The Very Small Monkey Who Couldn’t Put On His Pants

2018-03-09.abstract: The government continues to clamp down on media in the wake of a 2016 coup attempt. It already had more journalists in prison than any other country.
2018-03-09.snippet: The government continues to clamp down on media in the wake of a 2016 coup attempt. It already had more journalists in prison than any other country.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Turkish court sentenced 24 journalists to prison on Friday, ruling that they were linked to a religious sect that the government calls a terrorist group and that has been blamed for a failed coup attempt in 2016.
2018-03-09.headline_main: Turkey Sentences 24 Journalists to Prison, Claiming Terrorism Ties

2018-03-09.abstract: The president isn’t breaking with tradition. He’s exhibiting all of his country’s worst instincts.
2018-03-09.snippet: The president isn’t breaking with tradition. He’s exhibiting all of his country’s worst instincts.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Bad times are often interesting times. So it is with President Trump, whose insults and assaults have caused his critics to rethink what they know about their country. For the past year, American intellectuals have largely risen to the challenge, igniting new debates about race, class, gender and democracy itself. Whether these debates will translate into electoral victory remains unclear, but at least Mr. Trump’s foes are grappling with the forces behind his rise. The president’s critics realize that long-festering social divisions must be confronted.
2018-03-09.headline_main: When the Leader of the Free World Is an Ugly American

2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Louis Farrakhan, the 84-year-old head of the Nation of Islam, has been back in the headlines after a previously unreleased photo of him with President Barack Obama was published in January and Mr. Farrakhan gave an anti-Semitic speech at his organization’s annual convention last month.

(Other recent or current examples: “The Mentalist,” “Perception,” “Forever,” “A.P.B.,” “Lucifer.”)

2018-03-09.headline_main: The President and the Porn Star: A Story’s Slow Rise Above the Din

2018-03-09.abstract: How David Steward II, the publisher of Lion Forge, is trying to diversify the comics book industry, both on the page and behind the scenes.
2018-03-09.snippet: How David Steward II, the publisher of Lion Forge, is trying to diversify the comics book industry, both on the page and behind the scenes.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: On its website, the comic book publisher Lion Forge states that it is “committed to ‘Comics for Everyone.’” It reflects a particular passion of David Steward II, the chief executive officer of Lion Forge, which is based in St. Louis. “Not only is it the right thing to do, we thought the market was craving authentic characters who had appropriate representation,” Mr. Steward said in a recent phone interview. The approach seems to be working. In February, the Young Adult Library Services Association named “Lighter Than My Shadow,” a graphic novel by Katie Green about a young woman’s battle with eating disorders, one of the top 10 “great graphic novels for teens” published in 2017. During our interview, Mr. Steward, 40, talked about his career path, diversity in comics, the challenges of the industry and more. These are edited excerpts from that conversation.
2018-03-09.headline_main: ‘There Are a Lot of Stories That Need to Be Told’

2018-03-09.abstract: Noor Menai, president and C.E.O. of CTBC Bank U.S.A. in Los Angeles, finds life lessons in a movie, a song and a 300-year-old periodical.

2018-03-09.snippet: An irresistibly homey combination of parsnips, potatoes and duck legs creates a satisfying spin on a traditional dish.

2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Alicia Butcher Ehrhardt has it all figured out. With their three children grown and out of their New Jersey home, she and her husband, William, will move into a full-service retirement community this year. It will be someplace “interesting and affordable,” in her words, and, ideally, dry in the summer. “I don’t like humidity,” she said.
2018-03-09.headline_main: 7 Ways to Judge a Retirement Community’s Financial Health

2018-03-09.abstract: The opposition leader’s interview with The New York Times Magazine coincides with a renewed offensive against dissent.
2018-03-09.snippet: The opposition leader’s interview with The New York Times Magazine coincides with a renewed offensive against dissent.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: In The Times Magazine last week, I wrote about Venezuela’s descent into an unprecedented crisis. With extreme shortages of food and medicine, rampant crime in every province, a capital city with the highest murder rate in the world and one of the highest levels of inflation in recorded history, Venezuela is the most urgent humanitarian disaster in the Western Hemisphere, producing the largest exodus of refugees in the history of the Americas. At the same time, the prospect of political change seems vanishingly slender: As the country spirals down, President Nicolas Maduro is tightening his grip on power, invalidating opposition parties and forcing political rivals into exile and prison.
2018-03-09.headline_main: Leopoldo López Speaks Out, and Venezuela’s Government Cracks Down

2018-03-09.abstract: Mr. Shkreli, notorious for sharply increasing drug prices and for his attention-seeking antics online, was convicted last year of defrauding investors.
2018-03-09.snippet: Mr. Shkreli, notorious for sharply increasing drug prices and for his attention-seeking antics online, was convicted last year of defrauding investors.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli, a former pharmaceutical executive notorious for sharply increasing drug prices, mounting sneering defenses of his actions and even issuing a bounty for one of Hillary Clinton’s hairs, was sentenced on Friday to seven years in prison after being convicted of fraud last year.
2018-03-09.headline_main: Martin Shkreli Sentenced to 7 Years in Prison for Fraud

2018-03-09.abstract: Yve Laris Cohen’s piece, honoring Painting Space 122, is a conversation between painting and performance.
2018-03-09.snippet: Yve Laris Cohen’s piece, honoring Painting Space 122, is a conversation between painting and performance.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: The name PS122 has been the subject of discussion lately in the world of contemporary performance. In January, the organization known since 1980 as Performance Space 122, housed in a former public school building in the East Village, announced that it would now be called Performance Space New York. The change, timed to the building’s reopening after a renovation, caused an outcry among those who saw it as a generic rebranding, an erasure of the institution’s colorful history as a home for experimental live art.
2018-03-09.headline_main: Review: In ‘P.S. 122,’ Watching the Painters Paint and Scrape

A state, in this case Washington, was working to pass a bill that would institute a new payroll tax to help cover the cost of a much-needed service: long-term care in a nursing home, in a personal residence or elsewhere in the local community.

2018-03-09.snippet: Some of the biggest names in dieting, organic agriculture and preventive medicine died at surprisingly young ages.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, a geologist named Anatoli Brouchkov harvested some bacteria that had survived in the Arctic permafrost for eons. When the bacteria was injected into female mice, the compound seemed to extend their youth. Though Dr. Brouchkov is neither female nor a mouse, he wondered whether it could slow his own aging — and ate some of it.
2018-03-09.headline_main: The Secret to a Longer Life? Don’t Ask These Dead Longevity Researchers

2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: More than half a century since it was published, “A Wrinkle in Time,” the classic children’s book by Madeleine L’Engle, is finally hitting the big screen on Friday. 2018-03-09.snippet: Dr. Marvin, who had an asteroid and a mountain named after her, analyzed a chunk of a Soviet satellite and moon rocks retrieved by Apollo astronauts.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Ursula Marvin was a geologist at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in Cambridge, Mass., when she and her colleagues were asked to examine an extraterrestrial object: a 10-pound chunk of Sputnik IV, a Soviet satellite that had crashed, superheated at 1,535 degrees Celsius, onto a street in Manitowoc, Wis., before dawn on Sept. 5, 1962.

2018-03-09.headline_main: Florida Governor Signs Gun Limits Into Law, Breaking With the N.R.A.

2018-03-09.abstract: In limbo and in treatment, Harvey Weinstein has been lying low, still trying to work his Rolodex.
2018-03-09.snippet: In limbo and in treatment, Harvey Weinstein has been lying low, still trying to work his Rolodex.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein has been waking up early, checking in with his East Coast lawyers and then going down to a juice shop where he orders coffee and a green detox mix with kale and cucumber. He has lived with a roommate who was his sponsor during a truncated stint in sex rehab, sharing a 1,700-square-foot furnished apartment in a verdant glass complex convenient to a midrange shopping mall, said local residents and associates familiar with his circumstances, who would only describe Mr. Weinstein’s daily routine without attribution.
2018-03-09.headline_main: Where’s Harvey?

2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Jacques-Elie Ribeyron launched his industrial design-inspired jewelry line Ribeyron in 2015, with a collection of sculptural resin cuffs and buckled leather pieces. He expanded into accessories soon after, and last year he added ready-to-wear into the mix. This season, the Paris-based designer is broadening his offering in a far less expected way: He is launching a community outreach program alongside his fall/winter 2018 collection. Association Ribeyron is a project inspired by the multicultural Paris neighborhood of Couronnes, where Ribeyron has his studio. Its mission, the designer says, is to strengthen relationships between the area’s diverse communities through local events like open-invitation lunches in the neighborhood’s squares. “The idea is just to do something positive for the people around, and those who are often forgotten,” Ribeyron told T. The initiative will be funded by a percentage of sales from the brand’s fall/winter 2018 collection, when it hits SSENSE in July. The pieces — which range from a pink tie-dye T-shirt to a collection of oversize blazers in warm earth tones — were similarly inspired by dreams of small-town living. “I found myself a bit lost in this workload, so I made time to revisit memories in which my mom and I would go to New Hampshire in the summer and pass by these little villages surrounded by nature,” explains Ribeyron, who grew up in Canada. “I used this emotion and state of mind as the feeling for the collection.” ribeyron.eu — ANGELA KOH
2018-03-09.headline_main: 5 Things T Editors Like Right Now

2018-03-09.abstract: Jules Woodson reacts to the apology delivered by Andy Savage, a pastor at the Highpoint Church in Memphis, who admits to a “sexual incident” in 1998.
2018-03-09.snippet: Jules Woodson reacts to the apology delivered by Andy Savage, a pastor at the Highpoint Church in Memphis, who admits to a “sexual incident” in 1998.
2018-03-09.lead_paragraph: Jules Woodson says she was 17 when her youth pastor, Andy Savage, sexually assaulted her. In late 2017, almost two decades later, Ms. Woodson, inspired by the #MeToo movement, emailed Mr. Savage asking whether he remembered what has haunted her for decades. When he didn’t reply, she told her story to a blog for victims of church abuse. Days later, Mr. Savage addressed his congregation at the Highpoint Church in Memphis, where he is a pastor, and the church streamed the service online as usual.
2018-03-09.headline_main: I Was Assaulted. He Was Applauded.

2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: There are varying definitions of a sexless marriage or sexless relationship: no sex in the past year, no sex in the past six months or sex 10 or fewer times a year. According to one study, approximately 15 percent of married couples are sexless: Spouses haven’t had sex with each other in the past six months to one year.

2018-03-10.abstract: Before falling victim to the cellphone, the phone booth was a ubiquitous part of urban life. Now, it’s making a comeback, as a welcome refuge from open-plan offices.
2018-03-10.snippet: Before falling victim to the cellphone, the phone booth was a ubiquitous part of urban life. Now, it’s making a comeback, as a welcome refuge from open-plan offices.
2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: For much of the 20th century, the phone booth was a steadfast and essential installation of modern life, from bustling cities to tumbleweed-strewn desert gas stations. Tippi Hedren was attacked in one in “The Birds,” Clark Kent frequently changed to Superman in one and Bill & Ted used one to time-travel on their excellent adventure. In “The Matrix,” a phone booth was a portal — an exit device from the digital realm.
2018-03-10.headline_main: Dial P for Privacy: The Phone Booth Is Back

2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: Q. The city recently rolled out its organics pickup program in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where I live. It’s a pain to lug my organics down to the green market, so I was excited to be able to dispose of organic waste as I do my trash or recycling. The management of my large luxury rental, however, has not signed up for the program. My neighbors and I have been trying to engage management for months, with no luck. Is there anything I can do to persuade them, or will I just have to hope that the city eventually makes the organics program compulsory?

Another, which may give us a Trumpian tête-à-tête with Kim Jong-un, is his belief that he alone can solve the problem of nuclear proliferation.

2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: President Trump is in discussions with a veteran Washington lawyer who represented Bill Clinton during the impeachment process about joining the White House to help deal with the special counsel inquiry, according to four people familiar with the matter.
2018-03-10.headline_main: Clinton Impeachment Lawyer May Aid Trump in Mueller Response

2018-03-10.abstract: They need to see themselves reflected in stories that celebrate everyday beauty.
2018-03-10.snippet: They need to see themselves reflected in stories that celebrate everyday beauty.
2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: Atlanta — I’m pretty sure I hadn’t even wiped the sonogram goop off my belly before I rushed off to pick out dresses and books for my unborn child. I was on a mission: My daughter was going to need all the pink dresses and all the books with brown babies.
2018-03-10.headline_main: Black Kids Don’t Want to Read About Harriet Tubman All the Time

2018-03-10.abstract: In Japan, a girl turns to her Buddhist faith to help rebuild her village temple destroyed in the tsunami seven years ago.
2018-03-10.snippet: In Japan, a girl turns to her Buddhist faith to help rebuild her village temple destroyed in the tsunami seven years ago.
2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old girl, Masako Kobayashi, sat alone on a hill a few weeks after Japan was hit by an earthquake and tsunami in 2011, a disaster that struck on March 11, killed almost 16,000 people and led to the Fukushima nuclear plant meltdown. She gazed at the devastated land for hours. More than 200 residents of Kesen, her small community within the coastal city of Rikuzentakata, were dead. Of some 550 homes, all but two were destroyed. Most survivors left, but about 15 residents refused to abandon their town, living amid the debris for months without electricity or water.
2018-03-10.headline_main: A Young Monk Finds Her Calling

2018-03-10.abstract: Climate change has turned the dream of a failed 18th-century explorer into a reality.
2018-03-10.snippet: Climate change has turned the dream of a failed 18th-century explorer into a reality.
2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1789, a young fur trader named Alexander Mackenzie led an expedition in search of a Northwest Passage. He and his voyageurs and Chipewyan guides were attempting, 14 years before Lewis and Clark, to cross North America, paddling birch bark canoes down a river they hoped would pierce the Rocky Mountains. Mackenzie was a businessman who wanted to speed the pace of trade by connecting New York and China via an interior passage through the continent. He did find such a route, without knowing it. Mackenzie died thinking he was a failure, when he was really just 200 years early.
2018-03-10.headline_main: The Northwest Passage That Might Have Been

2018-03-10.abstract: It would be something like time traveling, only — unlike time travelers in the movies — I would know the future without having a chance to change it.
2018-03-10.snippet: It would be something like time traveling, only — unlike time travelers in the movies — I would know the future without having a chance to change it.
2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: This week I wrote the obituary of Sylvia Plath, the poet and the author of “The Bell Jar” (a staple of high school and college reading lists), for our Overlooked series, about women who deserved an obituary in The New York Times at the time of their death but did not get one.
2018-03-10.headline_main: The Challenge of Writing Sylvia Plath’s New York Times Obituary 55 Years After She Died

2018-03-10.abstract: It’s important to find just the right one when your world is falling apart.
2018-03-10.snippet: It’s important to find just the right one when your world is falling apart.
2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: Sure, we’ve all screamed into a pillow during a major life crisis or while trying to keep up with world events. But have we screamed into the best pillow? Here are reviews of some options.

2018-03-10.abstract: The Syrian man I’d known for years had been part of Al Qaeda’s leadership. He renounced violence and fled to Europe. Is he really no longer a threat?
2018-03-10.snippet: The Syrian man I’d known for years had been part of Al Qaeda’s leadership. He renounced violence and fled to Europe. Is he really no longer a threat?
2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: We met in a European city where he didn’t live, a neutral location on a quiet side street far from the crowds of shoppers and sightseers. To passers-by, he looked like a hipster, dressed in rust-colored skinny pants and a gray polo shirt. But he was not. I had known him for years in his native Syria. He was a onetime confidant of Abu Mohammad al-Jolani, then the leader of Al Qaeda in Syria.
2018-03-10.headline_main: The Ex-Jihadi in Plain Sight

2018-03-10.abstract: Some skiers who crashed in the treacherous conditions in Sochi, Russia, in 2014 fought to compete again, in Pyeongchang, with an altered perspective on life and their sport.
2018-03-10.snippet: Some skiers who crashed in the treacherous conditions in Sochi, Russia, in 2014 fought to compete again, in Pyeongchang, with an altered perspective on life and their sport.
2018-03-10.lead_paragraph: PYEONGCHANG, South Korea — Before racing in the men’s downhill on Saturday, strapped into a contraption that resembles a fitted chair suspended atop a single ski, Arly Velasquez closed his eyes at the starting gate. He had been waiting four years for this event, ever since he skidded down the track at the Sochi Paralympics in a horrific accident that battered his back and scarred his psyche.
2018-03-10.headline_main: Paralympic Skiers Confront the Scars That Linger From Sochi

2018-03-11.abstract: The Pathway Home was created to integrate troubled veterans into civilian life. A shooting rampage there showed just how difficult that journey is.
2018-03-11.snippet: The Pathway Home was created to integrate troubled veterans into civilian life. A shooting rampage there showed just how difficult that journey is.
2018-03-11.lead_paragraph: YOUNTVILLE, Calif. — The Pathway Home, a California program that treats troubled war veterans, is part of a large 19th-century veterans complex ringed by the famed vineyards of Napa Valley. Its mission-style buildings and mature stands of redwoods are worlds apart from the Middle Eastern deserts and mountains where many of its residents have fought — and left parts of themselves behind.
2018-03-11.headline_main: Violence Strikes a Veterans Program That Strove to Prevent It

2018-03-11.abstract: China’s legislature passed an amendment allowing Xi Jinping to stay longer than two terms as president. The move is about much more than the presidency.
2018-03-11.snippet: China’s legislature passed an amendment allowing Xi Jinping to stay longer than two terms as president. The move is about much more than the presidency.
2018-03-11.lead_paragraph: The roughly 3,000 delegates of the National People’s Congress, China’s legislature, voted almost unanimously on Sunday to end a two-term limit on the presidency, one of the main leadership posts held by Xi Jinping. While the overwhelming approval by the party-controlled congress was not a surprise, the repercussions go beyond just allowing Mr. Xi to stay on longer.
2018-03-11.headline_main: Ending Term Limits for China’s Xi Is a Big Deal. Here’s Why.

2018-03-11.abstract: If there is a Trump-Kim meeting, it will join a pantheon that includes Kennedy-Khruschev, Nixon-Mao, Bush-Putin and Obama-Castro. Some have been productive, some not.

2018-03-11.lead_paragraph: Kennedy would chide himself afterward for not doing his homework on Khrushchev. Nixon was unsure if he would even meet Mao despite months of quiet planning. And George W. Bush made what in hindsight was a classic first-impression misread of Vladimir V. Putin.
2018-03-11.headline_main: Summits of Adversaries: They Haven’t Always Worked Out So Well

2018-03-11.abstract: Joe LaCava has stood by Woods even when that meant idle time while the superstar recovered from surgery. “This guy’s been great to me and I love him like a brother,” LaCava says.

2018-03-11.lead_paragraph: PALM HARBOR, Fla. — Joe LaCava stood by Tiger Woods even when that meant sitting at home. For the better part of the past two years, caddie and player were separated by roughly 1,300 miles — LaCava in Connecticut, Woods in Florida — and a seemingly impassable expanse of uncharted territory as Woods entered his 40s and attempted to come back from several operations, including a back fusion last April.
2018-03-11.headline_main: In Tiger Woods’s Surging Play, a Steady Caddie

2018-03-11.lead_paragraph: More than 50 years since it first captured the hearts and expanded the minds of bookish young misfits, dreamers and in-betweeners around the world, “A Wrinkle in Time,” Madeleine L’Engle’s 1962 coming-of-age-as-interdimensional-odyssey novel, has finally materialized in theaters. The director Ava DuVernay’s adaptation, of a fantastical and cerebral story that many readers over the years had deemed unfilmable is one of the most anticipated movie events of the year – and one of the most polarizing.

2018-03-11.abstract: Will Mackin on his experiences in the U.S. Navy and turning them into fiction in his debut collection, “Bring Out the Dog.”
2018-03-11.snippet: Will Mackin on his experiences in the U.S. Navy and turning them into fiction in his debut collection, “Bring Out the Dog.”
2018-03-11.lead_paragraph: “I felt proud that I’d fought, or something like proud, but also glad it was over.” That’s the narrator of one story in Will Mackin’s debut collection, “Bring Out the Dog.” During his time in the United States Navy, Mr. Mackin was deployed with SEAL teams on assignments in Iraq, Afghanistan and elsewhere. When he came home, he relied on notes he kept during his time in combat to write these stories, three of which have appeared in The New Yorker. Below, Mr. Mackin talks about the experiences that inspired the book, why he chose to write fiction, a Pink Floyd lyric that has influenced his life and more.
2018-03-11.headline_main: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Turning SEAL Assignments Into Stories

Dormant ground cover is greening up through moldering leaf litter, and tiny green shoots are opening at the tips of saplings and woody shrubs.

2018-03-12.abstract: This week’s episode challenged Gabriel more than ever before.
2018-03-12.snippet: This week’s episode challenged Gabriel more than ever before.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Could Gabriel be the character best-equipped to cope with the constant degradation of life in a post-zombie world? Christian history valorizes those devoted few able to maintain the Lord’s course in times of great distress, martyrs and the self-sacrificial and their ilk. Gabriel has routinely staved off despair by falling back on his faith, trusting in God that all this suffering fits into some greater architecture toward salvation. But the writers are the closest thing “The Walking Dead” has to an omnipotent being, and they’re malevolent rulers.
2018-03-12.headline_main: ‘The Walking Dead,’ Season 8, Episode 11 Recap: Test of Faith

2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: KAKUMA, Kenya — These barren plains of sand and stone have always known lean times: times when the rivers run dry and the cows wither day by day, until their bones are scattered under the acacia trees. But the lean times have always been followed by normal times, when it rains enough to rebuild herds, repay debts, give milk to the children and eat meat a few times each week.
2018-03-12.headline_main: Hotter, Drier, Hungrier: How Global Warming Punishes the World’s Poorest

2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: The drama really began when the N.C.A.A. tournament expanded to 64 teams in 1985. Now anyone who could read and count had a neat, perfectly intelligible blank bracket to fill out. In the years since that expansion, memorable events have created a number of truisms about what transpires. Many are counterintuitive, favoring those upsets and surprising teams that we hold so dear.
2018-03-12.headline_main: March Madness Myths: N.C.A.A. Bracket Traps to Avoid

Arching over a gritty scrap-metal yard and railway line, the graffiti-scrawled 1,170-foot-long bridge links two of this city’s poorest neighborhoods.

2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Just before New Year’s Eve, my wife and I left our two young children at home with my parents and sneaked down to Havana for a brief getaway. You might be familiar with this uncanny sensation of kidlessness, as if you are getting away with something reckless and potentially illegal. More than once, I felt as if we had discovered a cheat code that had opened a portal into a parallel universe. Suddenly, we were allowed to get a drink. We were allowed to sip this drink. We could read more than a single page in a book at one time. We could enjoy a meal without cleaning yogurt off the ceiling.
2018-03-12.headline_main: Havana’s Symphony of Sound

2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: THE DANISH-NORWEGIAN WRITER Aksel Sandemose was a minor literary figure, a notorious crank, when he wrote the 1933 novel containing a set of commandments that would become one of Scandinavia’s defining social texts. “A Fugitive Crosses His Tracks” is a barely veiled send-up of his hometown, Nykobing Mors (renamed Jante) and an uncomfortably close-to-the-bone satire of Nordic conformity. Jante is governed by the “Law of Jante,” rules for living that reflect both Scandinavia’s ethnic homogeneity and its long-held belief that people are happier when both pleasure and pain are spread among all citizens:
2018-03-12.headline_main: A Low-Key Swedish Island’s Shockingly Modern Architecture

2018-03-12.abstract: Where to stay, eat, and shop on this bucolic island just a short flight from Stockholm.
2018-03-12.snippet: Where to stay, eat, and shop on this bucolic island just a short flight from Stockholm.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Surrounded by the Baltic Sea, about 60 miles off the southeastern coast of Sweden’s mainland, Gotland is the largest of the country’s bucolic islands (which number well over 200,000), and one that has a seemingly split personality. In the short summer season — primarily July and August, when temperatures hover in the balmy 70s — revelers descend on this mostly wild, windswept and sparsely populated province for all-night partying and the rambunctious weeklong electronic music festival Stockholmsveckan. Outside of high season, though — and anywhere outside of its largest town, Visby (population: 24,300) — Gotland remains a rural paradise, popular with outdoorsy Stockholm professionals looking to escape city life by hiking along the island’s craggy limestone cliffs and cycling past tiny clapboard fishing villages, crumbling medieval churches and 18th-century farmhouses. Several Stockholm-based architects have even chosen to build their own startlingly contemporary houses on the tradition-bound island.
2018-03-12.headline_main: A Guide to Gotland, a Rural Paradise Off the Swedish Coast

2018-03-12.abstract: As seen in “The Shape of Water,” it’s the mermaid’s male counterparts who’ve surfaced as objects of desire.
2018-03-12.snippet: As seen in “The Shape of Water,” it’s the mermaid’s male counterparts who’ve surfaced as objects of desire.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: The mermaid has long swum in the sea of our collective imagination, appearing in stories ranging from fourth-century B.C. Chinese mythology to the fairy tales of Hans Christian Andersen. Most often she is a princess of the depths, with alabaster skin, a giant fin in place of legs and breasts covered by a mess of long, tangled hair. Her appeal, though, is not merely aesthetic. For centuries, men have braved the open waters, knowing full well they may never make it home, and the mermaid has served as either a kind of ballast in times of trouble, saving sailors from floods and deadly storms, or a figure of seduction, luring them to their deaths at the bottom of the ocean. Her passivity, as well as her beguiling exoticness, is an escape from whatever drudgery awaits these men back on land — the mermaid is a fantasy, yes, but also a way to explain the unexplainable in nature. The admiral on one of Christopher Columbus’s expeditions once mistook a manatee, its silky gray curves moving gently through the Caribbean waters, for one.
2018-03-12.headline_main: The Latest Subject of Female Fantasies? Creatures From the Deep

2018-03-12.abstract: Prime Minister Theresa May’s remarks were an unusually direct condemnation of a country that Britain has been loath to blame for previous attacks.
2018-03-12.snippet: Prime Minister Theresa May’s remarks were an unusually direct condemnation of a country that Britain has been loath to blame for previous attacks.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s prime minister said on Monday that it was “highly likely” that Moscow was to blame for the poisoning of a former Russian spy attacked with a nerve agent near his home in southern England, and she warned of possible reprisals.
2018-03-12.headline_main: Britain Blames Moscow for Poisoning of Former Russian Spy

2018-03-12.abstract: Many Asian cuisines have been part of the landscape in the United States for decades, but only in recent years have Filipino dishes started gaining recognition outside immigrant communities.
2018-03-12.snippet: Many Asian cuisines have been part of the landscape in the United States for decades, but only in recent years have Filipino dishes started gaining recognition outside immigrant communities.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: In 1883, José Rizal, the future hero and martyr of the Philippine Revolution, was a homesick medical student abroad in Madrid. His longing for bagoong, a paste of seafood salted and left to ferment until it exudes a fathomless funk, grew so great that his worried family in Manila dispatched a jar. But it broke on the ship, releasing its pungent scent and, reportedly, terrifying the passengers.
2018-03-12.headline_main: Filipino Food Finds a Place in the American Mainstream

2018-03-12.abstract: Amid the excessive production values that make too much modern flamenco look synthetic, Jesús Carmona shows sunniness along with bravura.
2018-03-12.snippet: Amid the excessive production values that make too much modern flamenco look synthetic, Jesús Carmona shows sunniness along with bravura.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Everyone wants to think of flamenco as bubbling over with spontaneity, urgency and authenticity. Yet most of the flamenco that gets exported to us from Spain arrives intensely packaged with elaborate lighting, fancy costume changes and star personalities. Is Andalusia being evoked — or Las Vegas? Any evidence of the tradition’s raw vitality seems to have reached us through a net.
2018-03-12.headline_main: At Flamenco Festival, Finding the Force Beneath the Glitz

2018-03-12.abstract: Killings, death threats and “wanted” posters are used to intimidate advocates fighting the spread of tobacco to poor and middle-income nations.
2018-03-12.snippet: Killings, death threats and “wanted” posters are used to intimidate advocates fighting the spread of tobacco to poor and middle-income nations.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, more than a dozen men with AK-47s shot their way into Akinbode Oluwafemi’s home in Lagos, Nigeria. They killed his house guard and his brother-in-law, and briefly held a muzzle to the head of one of his year-old twins.
2018-03-12.headline_main: In Poor Countries, Antismoking Activists Face Threats and Violence

2018-03-12.abstract: A new offering from the Museum of Modern Art takes the guess work out of your macchiato.
2018-03-12.snippet: A new offering from the Museum of Modern Art takes the guess work out of your macchiato.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Recently, the Museum of Modern Art’s Design Store collaborated with students in the product-design program at the School of Visual Arts in New York on new items for its shops and catalog. Among them is a clever and generous lab-glass mug printed with the proportions of coffee, milk and water needed to prepare various drinks, like a macchiato, an Americano and a flat white. Irish coffee? You’re on your own: Multi-ccino Mug, $16 ($14.40 for members), MoMA Design Stores, 800-851-4509, store.moma.org.
2018-03-12.headline_main: The Mug That Makes Everyone a Barista

2018-03-12.abstract: A Colorado company specializes in honey from around the country while supporting an initiative to promote pollination for bees and butterflies.
2018-03-12.snippet: A Colorado company specializes in honey from around the country while supporting an initiative to promote pollination for bees and butterflies.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Local Hive, a company in Greeley, Colo., that was started as a family-run business in 1924, specializes in raw, unfiltered honey from across the United States. You will find subtle differences in color and taste. Honey from the Northeast is earthier than the fruity honey from Florida, for example. The company is donating some of the proceeds of every jar to PACE, a nonprofit global initiative to restore, protect and encourage pollination by bees and butterflies: Local Hive by Rice’s Honey, $6.99 for 16 ounces, localhivehoney.com.
2018-03-12.headline_main: Local Honey, Across the U.S.

2018-03-12.abstract: Diner Brew Company’s Bisou Miso is a delicate cider fermented with miso.
2018-03-12.snippet: Diner Brew Company’s Bisou Miso is a delicate cider fermented with miso.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: The brewer Chris Sheldon initially dismissed his roommate’s suggestion to brew apple cider with miso, an idea hatched over a meal of delivery sushi. But Mr. Sheldon left a marketing job to start his upstate cidery, Diner Brew Company in Mount Vernon, N.Y. so an odd ingredient was just one more challenge. The result is a surprisingly delicate cider that straddles sweet and savory, with a dry, floral streak of baking apples and a faintly saline undercurrent of white miso and umami: Diner Brew Company Bisou Miso, $9 at the Natural Wine Company, 211 North 11th Street (Roebling Street), Brooklyn, 646-397-9463, naturalwine.com. ORR SHTUHL
2018-03-12.headline_main: Hard Cider With a Miso Pedigree

2018-03-12.abstract: Breads from the French restaurant Vaucluse and pastries from Café Bilboquet are new options.
2018-03-12.snippet: Breads from the French restaurant Vaucluse and pastries from Café Bilboquet are new options.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: A crusty loaf of whole-grain bread to start a meal and some elaborate French pastry classics to end one are new options on the Upper East Side. Vaucluse, the French restaurant owned by Michael White’s Altamarea Group, is selling more than a dozen of its breads, baked by Jacqueline Eng, retail. Several are sourdough, including an unusual one, with a golden crumb, seasoned with turmeric, onion, pepper and ginger. Baguettes; whole grain and olive breads; even a dark chocolate flax Pullman are also on the menu. At Café Bilboquet, which opened a few doors east of Le Bilboquet last summer and becomes a wine bar in the evening, Bea Boumendil is fashioning an array of individual pastries, most notably an exquisite gâteau St.-Honoré. Both restaurants are also selling viennoiseries like croissants and pains au chocolat: Boulangerie V, Vaucluse, 100 East 63rd Street, breads to order two days in advance from shop.altamareagroup.com, for pickup at the restaurant from noon to 9 p.m. daily. Café Bilboquet, 26 East 60th Street, 646-869-4660, lebilboquetny.com.
2018-03-12.headline_main: Tasty Carbs on the Upper East Side

2018-03-12.abstract: The Berlin-based duo unveiled its new album, “Dimensional People,” using state-of-the-art software to pinpoint sounds in three-dimensional space.
2018-03-12.snippet: The Berlin-based duo unveiled its new album, “Dimensional People,” using state-of-the-art software to pinpoint sounds in three-dimensional space.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: SOMERVILLE, Mass. — Most bands introduce a new album with a tour, a radio performance, maybe a fan-club party. Mouse on Mars, the brainy, playful, long-running, relentlessly inventive electronic-music duo from Berlin, had a different kind of rollout for its new album, “Dimensional People.” The music went public at an academic conference presented here by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology called “Dissolve Music.”
2018-03-12.headline_main: Mouse on Mars at M.I.T.: A Symposium Becomes a Dance Party

2018-03-12.abstract: The recipe for Bogart’s Bitters was lost for nearly a century.
2018-03-12.snippet: The recipe for Bogart’s Bitters was lost for nearly a century.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: The name Jerry Thomas is to cocktails what Caesar Cardini is to salad. Thomas’s cocktail book from 1862 mentioned Bogart’s Bitters (sometimes rendered as Boker’s Bitters). The brand disappeared during Prohibition, and the recipe was lost. But Stephan Berg and Alexander Hauck, partners in The Bitter Truth, a global company based in Germany that sells cocktail ingredients, has a new offering based on the company’s analysis of a discovered bottle of the legendary bitters. The flavors are intense, dark and spicy, and the bitters are bottled with a vintage replica label in what is called a “lady leg” bottle. Use them sparingly in assorted cocktails: Bogart’s Bitters, The Bitter Truth, the-bitter-truth.com, sold at Astor Wines and Spirits, $34.99, 399 Lafayette Street (East Fourth Street), 212-674-7500, astorwines.com.
2018-03-12.headline_main: Legendary Bitters Return to the Mix

2018-03-12.abstract: An import from Kyoto, Japan, stands above the noise, with a silky texture and playful names.
2018-03-12.snippet: An import from Kyoto, Japan, stands above the noise, with a silky texture and playful names.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Recently, a colleague introduced me to Otokomae Tofu, imported from Kyoto, Japan. For someone like me, who tends to regard tofu as either soft or firm and as lacking personality in particular recipes, this brand is a revelation. It’s on the firm side, with the silky texture of custard. And it has a playful side: The packages, which come in single servings or a group of three, have dude-worthy names like Johnny Tofu, Three Guys in a Row and Strong Ken. Eat this tofu — most of which has an earthy, somewhat edamame flavor — as you would Greek yogurt, for dessert, topped with good preserves, even yuzu marmalade, or coated with a spoonful of caramel sauce: Otokomae Tofu, $1.99 to $6.89, Sunrise Mart, sunrisemart-ny.com, 646-380-9280, and Dainobu stores, dainobu.us, 212-645-0237.
2018-03-12.headline_main: Tofu That Can Make You Smile

2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Like all of us in the throes of #MeToo, I have been taking rigorous inventory of my sexual history, rolling back the tape on past highs and lows: the disturbing teenage experiences no longer chalked up to miscommunication, those times I gave in because it was easier, some unwanted advance successfully fended off.

2018-03-12.abstract: Spirulina smoothies, quinoa bowls, chicory salads: They’re all dining clichés. But so is the décor around them: brass sconces, midcentury chairs, tile mosaics.
2018-03-12.snippet: Spirulina smoothies, quinoa bowls, chicory salads: They’re all dining clichés. But so is the décor around them: brass sconces, midcentury chairs, tile mosaics.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: ON A FALL afternoon at De Maria, a year-old restaurant in New York’s NoLIta neighborhood, the flat city light pours in from a wall of windows onto square tables covered in worn pistachio-green and navy leather. Diners can sit on squat wooden chairs, a tan-leather banquette or felt-topped stools at the bar, which is lit by orblike pendants and backed by a Bauhaus-via-Brazil geometric tile mural. They might order a chai latte, which arrives in a stoneware mug made by Brooklyn’s Workaday Handmade, or a cured-salmon and coconut grain bowl, off seasonal menus that are available from early in the morning until late at night.
2018-03-12.headline_main: The Women Responsible for the Look of Your Next All-Day Cafe

2018-03-12.abstract: From gravity-defying braids to holographic-like eyes, the runways pushed the boundaries but still kept an element of realness in mind. Here, the fall/winter 2018 highlights.
2018-03-12.snippet: From gravity-defying braids to holographic-like eyes, the runways pushed the boundaries but still kept an element of realness in mind. Here, the fall/winter 2018 highlights.
2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Canary yellow, aqua, the brightest purple: These colors are not typically the stuff of fall palettes. But makeup artists gravitated toward multicolored eye makeup this season. At Sies Marjan, rings of Day-Glo orange and peppermint green — or crimson and ultraviolet — enclosed models’ eyes, complementing the collection’s saturated tones. (The designer Sander Lak is known to shun the color black.) At Altuzarra, the makeup artist Tom Pecheux treated eye makeup as watercolors, skirting forest green along the lower eyelid, dabbing turquoise on the outer edges just above the cheekbone and blending a wash of lilac up to the brow bone. An imperfect wing of dark liner was the final flourish. And, at Louis Vuitton, Pat McGrath played with negative space and applied racing stripes — in cobalt blue, red, yellow and asphalt gray — across the eyelids.
2018-03-12.headline_main: The Eight Biggest Beauty Trends from Fashion Month

2018-03-12.lead_paragraph: Testimony is expected to begin this week in the federal prosecution of Noor Salman, whose husband, Omar Mateen, killed 49 people at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., in 2016. Ms. Salman is charged with aiding and abetting her husband, who was killed in a shootout with the police, in “providing material support” to the Islamic State, and obstruction of justice. With so few facts available, it would be irresponsible to speculate about Ms. Salman’s possible role in this horrific event.

2018-03-13.abstract: She keeps finding new ways to fail our kids.
2018-03-13.snippet: She keeps finding new ways to fail our kids.
2018-03-13.lead_paragraph: On Sunday evening, CBS’s “60 Minutes” broadcast an interview that Lesley Stahl conducted with Betsy DeVos, Donald Trump’s education secretary and one of the richest members of his very rich cabinet. It was overwhelmingly seen as a disaster for DeVos, who struggled to answer very basic questions. She couldn’t say, for example, why schools in Michigan, her home state, have largely gotten worse since the widespread introduction of the school choice policies she lobbied for. When Stahl asked whether, as secretary, she’d ever visited a failing school to find out what went wrong, DeVos said, “I have not intentionally visited schools that are underperforming.”
2018-03-13.headline_main: Will Betsy DeVos Expand the School-to-Prison Pipeline?

2018-03-13.lead_paragraph: Since October, a mysterious flying object has been seen moving through the skies over the South Island of New Zealand. It looks like a cross between a small plane and a drone, with a series of small rotor blades along each wing that allow it to take off like a helicopter and then fly like a plane. 2018-03-13.abstract: The elder Williams earned her first victory over her sister since 2014 as Serena continued to shake off the rust from her long layoff last year.

2018-03-13.abstract: The playwright and actress recalls making an unexpected friendship in a Baltimore high school in the early 1960s, and feeling less invisible.
2018-03-13.snippet: The playwright and actress recalls making an unexpected friendship in a Baltimore high school in the early 1960s, and feeling less invisible.
2018-03-13.lead_paragraph: In 1961, there was a widely held theory among educated Baltimore Negroes, many of whom, like my mother, were teachers or administrators themselves, that if you wanted your children to have a good public school education, you should send them to a school that was predominantly Jewish, because Jews valued learning. And so I was sent not to the brand-new junior high that was built to service Negro students who were in desperate need of a better facility, but to Garrison Junior High in the Forest Park neighborhood, from which gentile whites had fled when the Jewish population moved in. I wasn’t “bused,” but I had to take two buses to get there.
2018-03-13.headline_main: Anna Deavere Smith: The First Time a White Person Wrote ‘Love’ to Me

2018-03-13.abstract: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2018-03-13.snippet: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2018-03-13.lead_paragraph: TRUTH By Hector Macdonald. (Little, Brown, $28.) Macdonald zeros in on the slipperiness of factuality, offering an array of case studies from the worlds of history, commerce and — of course — politics to make his case about how “truth” is used and misused. SEPARATE AND UNEQUAL By Steven M. Gillon. (Basic, $32.) The riots of the late 1960s, in cities like Detroit and Newark, left America reeling. In response, Lyndon B. Johnson put together the Kerner Commission, which concluded that “our nation is moving toward two societies.” Gillon tells the story of this commission and the debates it sparked. THE LITTLE BOOK OF FEMINIST SAINTS By Julia Pierpont. Illustrated by Manjit Thapp. (Random House, $18.) These page-long tributes, alongside paintings that look as if they belong on the side of votive candles, offer a new set of role models and heroes — “matron saints” — for the feminist future. IBN KHALDUN By Robert Irwin. (Princeton, $29.95.) The 14th-century Islamic legal scholar and theologian Ibn Khaldun is not as well remembered as some of his medieval European contemporaries, but Irwin’s biography makes the case for his presence in a range of fields, from literature to history. THE KREMLIN’S CANDIDATE By Jason Matthews. (Scribner, $26.99.) This is the third installment in the “Red Sparrow” trilogy — the first of which is now a film starring Jennifer Lawrence. He continues the story here with the tale of a Manchurian candidate, activated by none other than Vladimir Putin. This is, to be clear, a work of fiction.
2018-03-13.headline_main: New & Noteworthy

2018-03-13.lead_paragraph: Except for bonspiel regulars, curling seems only to break into popular consciousness once every four years, with the arrival of the Winter Olympic Games. This year, the sport that resembles shuffleboard on ice has popped up at a broad array of venues, from urban rooftop bars to remote frozen lakes, giving laypeople a last wintertime chance to hurl the stones through March. Here’s how to get on the ice.

2018-03-13.snippet: Pelota mixteca has been played for hundreds of years by indigenous people throughout the Americas. But it’s more than a competitive event.
2018-03-13.lead_paragraph: The men gather at an open field in a recreation area of the San Fernando Valley every Sunday, putting chalk to the dusty ground to draw the boundaries of a game that has been a weekly ritual as long as many can remember. After they are done, these men and others who filter in cluster into distinct teams, tossing a six-pound rubber ball to warm up.

2018-03-13.abstract: As I emerged from alcoholism, I had to face down a terrifying question.
2018-03-13.snippet: As I emerged from alcoholism, I had to face down a terrifying question.
2018-03-13.lead_paragraph: The first time I felt it — the buzz — I was almost 13. I didn’t vomit or black out or even embarrass myself. I just loved it. I loved the crackle of Champagne, its hot pine needles down my throat. We were celebrating my brother’s college graduation, and I wore a long muslin dress that made me feel like a child, until I felt something else: initiated, aglow. The whole world stood accused: You never told me it felt this good.
2018-03-13.headline_main: Does Recovery Kill Great Writing?

2018-03-13.abstract: The creation of man-made islands to host a new metropolis has come under fire from both local politicians and new rules in Beijing.
2018-03-13.snippet: The creation of man-made islands to host a new metropolis has come under fire from both local politicians and new rules in Beijing.
2018-03-13.lead_paragraph: Off the southern coast of Malaysia, a futuristic city is rising from the sea. An artificial island, the first of four that will anchor the projected $100 billion Forest City project, has materialized in the Straits of Johor, the channel that separates the Malay Peninsula from Singapore. Three years ago, this was open water. Today, a phalanx of half-built high-rises stretches across the new island, a flock of construction cranes hovering above. When completed, Forest City is expected to cover an area the size of four Central Parks and accommodate 700,000 residents. The metropolis will evoke a high-tech Atlantis, a “smart” eco-city where spacecraft-shaped towers will be draped with greenery, all motorized traffic will flow underground and every inch of the island cluster will be monitored by a state-of-the-art security system. In the words of a promotional video: “It is a pride and dream paradise for all mankind.”
2018-03-13.headline_main: A Malaysian Insta-City Becomes a Flash Point for Chinese Colonialism — and Capital Flight
